reviewText:
How to start to describe one of the greatest games ever made? Well.. that's probably one of the reasons why I never did a review.

Fallout has been, still is and probably will always be my favourite game (series) of all time. Ever since I first laid eyes on the game, somewhere back in 1997, I wish I could live in that same apocalyptic world. The perfect blend of a post-nuclear environment and 50's style, makes it unique and is the reason why I would pick this game over other great games like Baldurs Gate or Planescape Torment.

Like many RPG's, you start of creating your character. Besides sex, there are no cosmetic changes. You do get to alter your skill points and perks. Depending how you create your character, you might get a whole different adventure, each time. Play as a female? You might get some unique conversations. Low intelligence? You can't even speak properly.

The gameplay is real-time but turn-based in combat. You can do actions, based on your Action Points (AP) and so do your enemies. You can even aim on one of your enemies' parts; cripple his leg, shoot his head or bust his groin... it's all up to you. Your opponents often die in gruesome ways and there are tons of different weapons (melee, guns, heavy weapons, unarmed, energy), different armors for you to wear, tons of items and lots of (side) quests, so you won't get bored quickly.

The writing in the game is exceptional. Most of the dialogue are interesting and often combined with a lot of (dark) humor. In my opinion, the humor is one of the best aspects of what describes Fallout, something Bethesda never got right (in Fallout 3). Only important NPC's have dialogue, which are often voiced by (former) celebrities like Dwight Schulz & Richard Dean Anderson. The narration is done by Ron Perlman, who rightfully became a Fallout Icon, over the years.

The music, produced by Mark Morgan, is also excellent. It's without a doubt, one of the best soundtracks of any game. The experimental music creates the apocalyptic atmosphere, perfectly.

I highly recommend Fallout to every RPG lover out there. I could write a lot more about why I like Fallout but it all comes down to this: It's simply one of those games you have to play before you die.

reviewText:
Let me begin by noting that I was introduced to the Fallout series with Fallout 3, back in around 2009.
I put hundreds of hours into the game between Xbox 360 and PC, and I found the world to be incredibly interesting and atmospheric. The RPG mechanics and depth were like something I had never before seen, being a teenager and my life having been more saturated with more casualized games such as Call of Duty.
Up until I finished Fallout, Fallout 3 was my all-time favorite.
But now that I've experienced Fallout, it's as if my standards have risen tenfold. It may seem weird given that the game is seventeen years old as of writing this review, but I can elaborate. This game has managed to deliver an experience like no other game I have ever played with simple isometric graphics, and most importantly, a surprisingly complex and mature narrative.
The music, sounds, and intriguing -- but again, simple -- visuals create an ambient feeling of loneliness  throughout the wasteland. The soundtrack is hauntingly fitting, for example in Necropolis, a city of ghouls. The sound creepy churchbells amid a fine chord of a low key sends shivers down my spine.
Adult themes similar to the philosophy of the Ubermensch, and existentialism are very prevalent as well.
I love this game, and it has shown me the real potential of video games. Books present you with narrative. Films, with narrative, visualization, and sound. Video games, with narrative, visualization, sound, and interaction.

10/10

reviewText:
Where to start with this game...

'It's a classic' would be a good place to start, I guess. I have no problems say that from the outset. It's only taken me 15 years to get around to play original Fallout, but I can see without a shadow of a doubt why it's so highly regarded.

Before you play this game make sure to download the Fallout Fixt mod, which is a very comprehensive community mod which fixes a lot of the bugs, and more importantly the resolution for modern monitors. Without this patch you'll more than likely experience a horrible rainbow pixalation effect during videos and gameplay.

Anyway...

Fallout is a turn-based RPG series which offers you various ways to tackle the game. Do you want to be a stealthy person, creeping around, pick pocketing your way to glory? Sure, why not! Do you want to be a smooth talking kinda guy who can talk his way in and out of trouble? Go on, be that guy! What about a bookworm who can use his brain to solve puzzles. Yup! And of course you can be a mix of all three, as well as a gun totting maniac! YEE-HAW!
For my playthrough I used one of the pre-set characers (Albert) who was a Lawyer in a previous life and was set up with high charisma and speech skills. This opened up different dialogue trees throughout the game, which was nice.

Anyway, I enjoyed this game - I enjoyed it a lot. The characters are great, the voice acting (while limited) was pretty nice (though it did give away who the 'important' characters were) and the story itself was pretty deep. The game starts, as always, with you the 'Vault Dweller' leaving your vault for the first time to explore the wastelands. You're tasked with bringing back a water chip to save your vault before everyone dies of thirst!
There's a time limit to this, which (for me) cast a sense of urgency. Normally in Fallout games (Fallout 3 and New Vegas) I'm guilty of just going 'WHEEEEE' and exploring everywhere and not really caring what I'm doing. Yet in Fallout there's no time to explore, you've got to save lives!
... if you want to.

You see you don't NEED to save their lives, if you don't want to. In fact, you don't HAVE to do much in Fallout if you don't want to. It's not a narrow pathed experience, you can pretty much choose how you deal with the events in the game (and the end game cutscene will reflect on this at the end). A lot of games claim to be an open experience, and the actions you take reflecting on the game world, yet here's a game from 1997 which actually does that. I'm not sure it even heralds that fact that it does this. It just gets on with being a pretty damn good game.

This brings me on to another aspect of the game - the many different branches of the game. People react to you differently depending on what you're wearing, what you're wielding, and what you're intelligence or charisma is. I find that amaizng now (in 2014), so I can only imagine how mindblowing it was back in 1997 when the game was released. The 'simple' graphics by today's standards shouldn't distract you from what is a very complex game. There's a lot going on under the hood of this game and at times perhaps too much.
My eyes were really opened up to this towards the end of the game when I was struggling with killing a certain mob. I had went about it 'head on' and was killed a number of times. Yet, after a night's sleep I came back with a different approach, a more sneaky ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s approach and it was so much easier, and strangely satisfying. I had killed the guy and he had never even seen me.
OK, sure the wastelands were plunged into another 100 years of nuclear fallout in the process, but hey... I KILLED THE GUY!

However, even with the Fallout Fixt mod, the game can be prone to crash now and again. I'm not sure if it's the game's memory file getting too big or a conflict with Steam Overlay (wouldn't be a first), but towards the end of the game (and a lot of different quest outcomes) it started to become slightly unstable. So save REGULARLY!

Which brings me on to another thing. This is an 'old school' game. It will not autosave for you, you must take control of your own save files. If you die you won't be taken back to the next/recent checkpoint... you'll have to load up from the last point you saved.
This was the only thing I didn't like, but in the end I learned to live with it and it made me realise how pampered I had become as a gamer. I didn't have autosaves and 10 minute interval checkpoints when I was a kid and I still played games all the time back then. Yet, here I am as a grown man crying about dying and having to go back 20 minutes in the game because I had forgot to save... a lesson in life this game has given me.
Also, this game is tough. REALLY tough. Depending on how you build your character, or which character you choose. You will die a lot.
A lot.

So in closing...

If you're looking for an old school RPG experience than I'd recommend giving Fallout a try. I appreciate at time of writing they're no longer available on the Steam Store, or GOG, but hopefully they return one day, as they deserve to be played.

reviewText:
First of all, I'd like to note that this review is made by someone who has recently picked this game up - no nostalgia, only objectivity.

The good:
- Works well, zero crashes so far, one very minor bug (Shady Sands citizen was panicking over Tandi when she wasn't even gone yet). Zero compatibility issues - they have seriously taken GOOD care of the game when they made it available on Steam (I believe it's even running on some MS-DOS emulator but you don't notice a thing about that. Also it comes with some sort of resolution patch). Also, the game is very alt-tab friendly, you can alt-tab at any time without issues.
- Very good story so far (10 hours in, so can't say everything about it, but so far it's been really good). This game is all about the dialogue. There's an amazing amount of text in this game - and many characters even have spoken dialogue and animations when you're talking to them. I'd go as far as saying the story is on pretty much the same level as 3 and NV so far, in my opinion - with better character building than NV, but more of an RPG touch than FO3 (but I know opinions differ greatly on this part, so take it with a grain of salt, and feel free to disagree).
- This game has aged very well. I don't exactly know how to explain it, but I actually guess the closest analogy would be the old Pokémon games, gameplay-wise. Top-down view, grid based, turn-based combat. 2D games like this never really get old. You can try to make them look better but it'll just end up looking weird.
- Price. This game is dirt cheap, I got it for about €1,50 during the summer sale.

Neutral:
- It's a hard game. It definitely is less forgiving than Fallout 3 or Fallout New Vegas. Don't be surprised to find a surprisingly large group of surprisingly strong raiders in your path at an early level. And even if you've played FO3 and FONV, you will more likely than not screw up your S.P.E.C.I.A.L. which means you'll have to start over and make a new character early on. The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. and stats and perks are all rather complicated. I actually like it, though, despite having to start over because I have 1 strength and can't use my guns properly.

The bad:
-Resolution. It's locked to 4:3, and although the Steam version seemed to have some sort of Resolution patch and you can set it to your native resolution which lets you alt-tab quicker, you'll still have to either deal with pillarboxing or stretching. The textures also aren't of amazing resolutions, but that doesn't bother me much personally. The art style is amazing.
- Might be hard to get hooked. Older games aren't for everyone and I understand that. I definitely love it though - and I only bought it during this summer sale. Never played it before. Hell, I was 3 years old when this game was released...

Verdict:
I personally think this game is easily worth the price they ask for it during a sale. It's old, but they took good care of it when they made it available on Steam. Give it a try!

Edit - 18-1-2016
I actually did end up playing this game a lot. However, I played it on my phone, in an emulator, so it still shows only 10.0 hours on Steam

reviewText:
This is it. The Post-Apocalyptic RPG game that began a revolution and changed everything about the genre.

PROS:

- Well written story that will keep you interested until the end.
- Charismatic and very well developed characters.
- Karma and choice system (every positive and negative choice you made will count for the rest of the adventure).
- Complex and complete interactive system and turn-based combat system.
- The precise aiming system allows you to play strategically in battles (disable an enemy specific limb, blind it, stunt it, etc).
- The S.P.E.C.I.A.L. system gives the game an amazing way to improve the main protagonist skills/perks.
- High quality 2D graphics with exceptional animations (for its time) that gives the characters/enemies great personality and a unique style.
- Music that gets you into a decadent atmosfere on a wasted and post-apocalyptic Earth.
- Excellent voice acting (many of those actors are highly recognized stars from the cinema and TV)
- Innovative buying/selling and trading system.
- Very accurate Point-and-click controls for pointing enemies, weapons, items, lockers, treasure chest, etc.

CONS:

- A pair of minor graphical glitches due to its age.

If you love turn-based RPGs, you like the atmosphere from the Mad Max movies and you don't care to travel in time to the 90's (technologically speaking). this game will assure you hours of fun and satisfaction.

My Score: 9/10

Note: Played it on Windows XP - SP3

reviewText:
An amazing game that laid the groundwork for an outstanding series. The first is still enjoyable today and you can see that not much has changed since 1997. Perks, SPECIAL, Pip-boy, manual targeting, character creation, leveling. It's all here. The only thing you won't find is real time combat because the game forces you into a turn-based system. That will take some time to get used to if you're a FPS player.

The real shame is that most of the younger fans won't even give the first two games a go because of the graphics. The same can be said of the older players who refuse to accept the new games. I'm somewhere in the middle. I started out with Fallout 1 & 2, but I didn't become a hardcore fan until Fallout 3 and New Vegas. They all have their pros and cons, but the atmosphere and gameplay have remained mostly the same.

There is a community of fans still developing bug fixes and resolution patches for this game. If you are a true fan then you owe it to yourself to play this. Might as well do it now while it still works on modern computers.

reviewText:
The original Fallout is hardly as accessible as its modern, 21st century sequels, however it is just as brilliant, if not more so, than the both of them put together. With fewer sidequests and a shorter main story, it isn't nearly as long as Bethesda's contributions to the series, however it more than makes up for that thanks to its incredible atmosphere and high levels of replayability.

Now that I've gotten the necessary comparisons out of the way, I'd like to refrain from mentioning Fallout 3 and New Vegas from this point onwards. Yes, New Vegas ties into this game's story quite a fair bit more (considering 3 is something of an offshoot), however what it comes down to is those are two ultimately different games. What you're getting here is a turn-based strategy RPG that is dowright fantastic.

I'll freely admit that the game didn't have me very intrigued when I first booted it up. The graphics were plain, the controls and interface decidedly confusing, and the mechanics unclear. However, after sticking through the game's beginning and unlocking both the world's and the story's fullest potentials, the brilliance of the experience washed over me; this is a game that is entirely dynamic. Every single action your player character takes has an effect in a far more dramatic way than most games, and a whole ton of things can vastly change based on how you respond to the challenges presented to you. I am entirely certain that after my first playthrough last week, I haven't even begun to experience the full depth of what this game has to offer.

The battles in the game are initially unexciting, yet quickly become more unique. The Action Points" system
recommended: is still creative enough that so many years later it remains capable of keeping my attention and excitement at a high
hoursPlayed: something very rare of older RPGs (which are often plagued by interface and gameplay issues that could only be resolved later on with more powerful hardware and higher resolutions). My one gripe is the randomness of the critical hits found later on in the game; some seem to inflict so much damage to the player character that it is impossible not to be killed by them
voteText: even when at the level cap and using full power armor. This element of randomness is not appreciated given that it can instantly end the life of even the most well-prepared vault dweller. I also highly recommend you refrain from picking up the "Bloody Mess" perk
helpfulPercent: as it makes the gory death animations all the more satisfying when they do crop up.\n\nAnd make no mistake
votesHelpful: they will crop up over the course of your playthrough
votesTotal: and when they do it is both grim
votesFunny: satisfying
commentsCount: and oddly hilarious. Watching a supermutant clutch at his stomach while guts spew out of them may at first leave you with a grimace on your face
column16: and yet there's someting oddly humorous about the timing of the worm crawling out of his head when he's already been laying on the ground dead for a couple of seconds.\n\nUltimately
column17: it's the little details that make Fallout such an incredible game
column18: especially given how they're able to factor into the overall experience. If you're willing to overlook an initially obtusely difficult set of game mechanics and UI elements
column19: as well as some lacklustre graphics and annoying grammatical errors
column20: what you'll unearth in the original Fallout is a dynamic RPG classic that is entirely deserving of its reputation as one of the greatest Western RPGs to have emerged from the lates 90s."

reviewText:
The original Fallout is a turn based RPG.  You create, control, and level up a single character, but you can also recruit others to your cause.  Unfortunately, followers can only have their weapons upgraded in the vanilla version of the game; however, with Fallout Fixit, they can level up and have the armor upgraded like in Fallout 2.
The game is short by RPG standards -only about 20 hours- but a low price should offset such concerns.  Furthermore, the time that you do spend in game is what I refer to as quality game play time;  in other words, there are no boring and repetive quests or other filler content that increases game time without really adding to the game.  Your time spent in Fallout 1 will be filled with lighting raiders on fire, taking headshots on super mutants, performing unique side quests, and collecting all manner of new and destructive weapons.
Unfortunately, Fallout 1 is not without it's flaws.  For one, the grapics are quite dated.  If beautiful graphics are a requirement for you, then you might want to skip this one.  Second, the inventory interface is rather clunky.  Such an interface would probably be considered unacceptable by modern standards, but it's not bad enough that it should destroy your ability to enjoy the game.  Finally, there are other small concerns (such as the inability to move followers that get in your way).  However, these are mostly fixed by the Fallout Fixit patch.  In fact, I highly recommend this patch (see the Steam Forums or do a Google search).  It restores some cut content, makes followers more useful/powerfull, includes the high resolution patch, and much more.
The game may be showing its age when it comes to graphics and a clunky interface, but RPG lovers willing to look past these flaws will find a diamond in the rough.  The RPG mechanics are quite satisfying and the world and atmosphere are so captivating, that even after 15 years and 4 other Fallout games, fans still can't get enough.

reviewText: One of the first real modern cRPGs and part of the late 90s cRPG revival which is now in old school territory. This single character classless turn-based isometric RPG is still considered a high-water mark of the genre. The quests can be completed multiple ways using multiple character types. The game is loaded with skill checks.  Combat, speech, and stealth paths are all viable and supported heavily right through to the end game. Replays are a must in order to witness this amount of depth.  The writing and voice acting is top notch and the dark/humorous post nuclear setting in an alternate retro-future timeline as imagined by 1950s America is something SPECIAL.\n\nPerhaps the most controversial element is the time limit but I'd argue it adds a good sense of urgency lacking in nearly every other RPG. Truth is it's very generous and can be extended.  For those of us who played the game many times, it's actually moot since the game can be completed in 30 minutes if you know what you are doing.

reviewText: Fallout 2 is the better game. The mixture of a big world, plenty of unique NPCs, many side quests, complex dialogue trees, and a nice amount of adult-themed humor and social critique are still unsurpassed.\n\nHowever, Fallout 1 just oozes that dark, gritty atmosphere. The future happens to be a grim place. The awesome  atmospheric soundtrack, the memorable characters you meet (often with a well-aimed critical shot to the crotch), and the broken towns and nuclear wastelands you visit during your journey through southern California all contribute to that special post-apocalyptic feel" in ways that Fallout 2 can't quite copy

reviewText:
The Fallout world is my favourite fictional world, period. The lore is deep and intelligent, and packed full of interesting characters, concepts, and secrets for the player to learn about and discover. The debut Fallout game itself is a classic RPG by an measure, and one of the best RPGs of the 90s.

While not as accessible as the most recent games in the series, Fallout doesn't lack charm and depth, and for those with the patience to tackle a game that's part classic RPG, part adventure game, it holds a wealth of wonderful fiction to discover.

However, As much as it was a great achievement in terms of storytelling and world-building, it is a product of its time and thus suffers from some of the problems that plagued both the aforementioned genres in the 90s: clunky UI, an isometric camera that often impedes movement and blocks items and people, combat that relies utterly on chance with little skill involved, unforgiving difficulty for beginner characters, and - worst of all IMO - illogical solutions to problems that can leave unwitting players frustrated.

You didn't think to use a radio on that one particular computer? Too bad, buddy, you're stuck

Fallout 2 is bigger, streamlines some of the technical issues and irons out some unintuitive features, but I think that this is the superior game when it comes to plot, tone, and narrative. The fantastic voice acting from some great performers coupled with the driving storyline really draws you in and makes you feel like there is something real at stake. The narrative and the world really are the game's strongest features. Complaints aside, I do recommend that any fan of the Fallout series commit some time to discovering this game, and delving deeper into the world of Fallout.

Trust me when I say this, this game may be old but its honestly better then most RPGs out today, the things you discover while out exploring the world will truly leave you with your mouth hanging open! Once you start playing you wont want to stop, you'll wana keep playing unril your sure you've explored every nook and cranny, talked to every NPC, and blew the face off of every enemy you encounter!

reviewText: The Fallout Series has always been a favorite of mine. When I first played Fallout 1, I sucked so much at it. (Although this can be traced back to the fact that I actually didn't play very many turn based games) At times I would stop playing due to its difficulty, but after a while you get the hang of it. My suggestion would be if you like old school turn based RPG's that can be a challenge, definitely buy this game. The story is fantastic and the gameplay is fun yet challenging. The only complaints would be the few bugs here and there as well as the ending. There's nothing wrong with the ending itself, its just that after you beat the game you cannot continue with your save. Kinda sucks, but other than that the game is flawless. It will always be one of my favorite games of all time.

reviewText:
Legendary role-playing game with very sophisticated turn-based battle system and supreme universe of dark age after nuclear war.

And, finally, it is working properly on Steam, with convenient High Res fix, which was really needed!

I remember buying the game 2 years back, and it was without that fix back then. So it was lost for many players, until some wizardry wind (probably from GOG galaxy), turned this game alive once more. Now it is more stable and reliable on Windows 7 and upper, than Fallout 3.

Another fix I've noticed from my previous experience - they cut all kids from the game, so you can't kill them and become child killer now. Good thing, even if it is a restriction for somebody role-playing a maniac. There are too many of them around us already.

What else can I say? The game is a must-have for any real fan of true role-playing games and tough turn-based fights. It is much better than all three new Shadowrun games, in scenario, in combats, and overall complexity.

Multiplicity of choices on every step, and various consequences for every step you'll made. Very clever opponents, even overpowered for modern casual players. And that unforgettable feeling of frontier, with that leather armor from old Mad Max on your shoulders.

An essence of western role-playing games. 10/10 mark, as goes with all golden bars of gaming in my collection.

reviewText:
An amazing isometric RPG with a post-apocalyptic theme, Fallout has become one of my go-to games when in need of a serious RPG nostalgia trip. The series is my favourite series of all time, for good reasons.

Pro's:
+ Amazing depth, with interesting skills and perks, making for awesome character development.
+ Fantastic story with multiple endings, and long/short ways to achieve those endings.
+ Engrossing world with interesting characters, quests and background stories to really set the mood of the wasteland.
+ Steam edition includes some nice UI touches with the widescreen mod built-in.
+ Combinations of points 1 & 2 make for exceptional replayability with different characters each time.

Con's:
- Unforgiving (Not really a con to me as I enjoy the challenge) Daunting for new RPG players unfamiliar with the genre.
- Still some minor bugs present throughout the years.
- Some redundant perks that can seem good at first pick and then become useless.

reviewText:
War. War never changes.
The Romans waged war to gather slaves and wealth. Spain built an empire from its lust for gold and territory. Hitler shaped a battered Germany into an economic superpower.

But war never changes.

In the 21st century, war was still waged over the resources that could be acquired. Only this time, the spoils of war were also its weapons: Petroleum and Uranium. For these resources, China would invade Alaska, the US would annex Canada, and the European Commonwealth would dissolve into quarreling, bickering nation-states, bent on controlling the last remaining resources on Earth.

In 2077, the storm of world war had come again. In two brief hours, most of the planet was reduced to cinders. And from the ashes of nuclear devastation, a new civilization would struggle to arise.

A few were able to reach the relative safety of the large underground Vaults. Your family was part of that group that entered Vault Thirteen. Imprisoned safely behind the large Vault door, under a mountain of stone, a generation has lived without knowledge of the outside world.

Life in the Vault is about to change.

reviewText:
Very few games do what Fallout 1 does.

Very few games let you play the entire campaign without firing a single shot or killing a single creature. Fallout 1 does

Very few games manage to tell a meaningful dark story while also making you laugh at jokes and references. Fallout 1 does.

Very few games capture the table top rpg experience without losing much during the transition to video game. Fallout 1 does.

Very few games provide a level of replayability that the experience is still exciting years later. Fallout 1 does.

Fallout 1 gets so many things right it quickly becomes clear why it overshadowed the very material it was based upon. It has so many short comings and problems and graphically it doesn't stand the test of time as well as other games but to the individual who is willing to take the time to learn the systems and get involved in the world the game offers up will have the potential to lose many hours and restful sleeps as you always want to go on one more adventure or try something in a different way.

The game is a true role playing experience, to enjoy it for what it offers you need to become less of a power gamer and instead focus on rolling with the punches and taking leaps of faith as you forge the story and personality of your character. You need to become the person who enjoys reading text and develop a love for turnbased combat. Fallout 1 isn't for everyone and coming here from fallout 3-current is going to be jarring and difficult for some, and that is alright, but it is worth the money and time to at least give it a chance as the game rewards you with an experience no other game really has matched.

The steam version of this game runs fine on modern hardware with little to no setup however installing the fan made community patch 'Fallout Fixit will make your experience far less buggy
hoursPlayed: and clean.\n\nI could not recommend fallout enough and it is easily in my top ten games of all time."

reviewText:
A post-apocalyptic classic.

Before anything else, let me begin by saying that Fallout is very outdated and if you have never played it but decided that it's about time to give it a try - just like me - there's a possibility that you're going to dislike it at first. The interface is far from friendly, the graphics are obviously subpar, there's no hand-holding and the difficulty is unforgiving.

With that said, once you delve into the game and truly immerse yourself in the post-apocalyptic world, you're going to love every single piece of it. Either fight your way through the desert or just sneak past the things severely affected by radiation, be helpful towards people or let everyone cope with their problems, talk others into things or just kill everyone to get them out of your way...

Everything is up to you in this classic role-playing game, but keep in mind that whatever you do has an effect on the world. Now go and face your first decision - will you rescue the people asking for your help by finding a water chip, or let them die of dehydration and go mind your own business instead?

reviewText:
Fallout is one of those games that you just never forget. It's world and storyline just sticks with you and becomes part of the basis on which you judge all other games. It is a game that changes all of your preconceptions of how an RPG should play out. What is good? What is evil? Fallout is a game that ask you what is most important, the intention to do good or the end result being good despite the intention. Nothing is simply black and white and nobody's actions are simple.

Fallout starts out simple enough, you are a Vault Dweller. Living beneath the earth sheltered from the nuclear devastation above you have never had to worry much about anything until now. Your vault's water chip has failed and there is no spare on hand so the Overseer, the supreme ruler of the vault, nominates you to be the first person ever to leave vault and go forth and procure a new water chip.

As you leave the vault and begin to travel the outside wasteland you quickly find that you are not the only survivors in this post-apocalyptic world. Other vaults and just plain resourceful people have managed to build communities and the world is rebuilding, for the most part. As you travel around to these communities and their inhabitants question your sanity as you question them about vault's and water chips you quickly realize that a greater threat looms in the horizon, one that neither you nor your vault can ignore for long.

Fallout is an isometric with turn based combat, you can recruit companions along the way but the lack of any direct control over them makes them rather suicidal, or in the case of the ones using burst weapons, makes you rather suicidal. The combat is not particularly brilliant but works well enough that you won't get annoyed with it until many playthroughs in.

You advance your character using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system, Strength

votesHelpful: and have a multitude of skills to help you along the way. Many of the skills are non-combat related and having high skills or stats can open up new conversation options and previously unseen ways of completing quests and objectives. Most notable is the low intelligence options. While having a low intelligence

reviewText:
Summary: Post-apocalyptic isometric turn-based RPG
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 20 hrs
Cards: No
Cloud: Yes

Yep. Still good after nearly 20 years. Fallout presents a world that has been devastated by the nuclear apocalypse. Underground containment facilities known as Vaults house the last remnants of humanity and the battle for survival has begun.

Fallout uses a hex-grid isometric turn-based combat system. Combat blends seamlessly into its map system, much like games made with the Infinity Engine. It's a fun system, but there's only one problem I have with it - everything takes its turn one at a time. This becomes problematic when there's 20 things on the screen and you spend more time watching the computer make its moves compared to your single move. If there was a way for all NPCs to take their turn at the same time, that'd be a vast improvement.

For the most part the game aged well. The steam version includes tweaks to help it run on modern systems, which helps immensely. The chat interface is still rather confining, but you get used to it.

There's a lot of freedom in Fallout.  I have an unhealthy obsession with making and optimizing new characters to suit my play style. You can gun down friend and foe alike, devastate entire towns, and still complete the game. Even though there doesn't feel like there's a lot of quests, Fallout actually takes a fair amount of time to get through without speedrunning.

But I can sum up why we love the game - Power Armor. After mowing down hordes of raiders while wearing naught but leather, it's satisfying to procure the ultimate badass protection in the land. Oh yessss. And you can reinforce it for good measure!

Fallout will likely remain among my favorites for years to come. Being able to create new character concepts and impose new challenges upon myself, I will happily play the game yet again in ten more years. I rate this a 9/10.

reviewText:
This is it. The beginning of the Fallout franchise. And what a beginning it was.
Fallout (along with its sequel, Fallout 2, and the spinoff Fallout Tactics to an extent) is an isometric, turn-based cRPG. The main premise of Fallout is surviving in a heavily destroyed post-apocalyptic world ravaged by nuclear warfare. The post-apocalyptic setting of Fallout is influenced greatly by other forefathers of the post-apocalyptic genre in fiction, most notably the Mad Max films and Wasteland, the video game. Interestingly enough, Fallout established itself as an immense influence in the genre not long after the game's release, becoming an iconic flagship of the setting for years to come.
The game uses a top-down perspective, and characters can move in six directions, within a hexagonal grid. Combat in the game is based on using this grid-based movement system to move your character around the battlefield, and attack/do other actions using action points. Each character is granted a limited number of action points (AP) per turn, and when their AP runs out, the turn ends, and the enemy party is allowed to act. Fallout's combat system places a large emphasis on planning and forethought, and also on smart and informed character building. Fallout is apparently well-known for its difficulty, and although I disagree with it being a particularly hard game, it may still be difficult for new players to get into because of the depth of the gameplay mechanics, and how relatively badly they're documented within the game itself. While I by no means want to imply that Fallout is cryptic, there are still plenty of things within this game that are tougher for new players to grasp. The game has no real tutorial, and some of the menus are cluster♥♥♥♥s to navigate, resulting in the game taking a while to learn how to play fluently.
Albeit the combat of the game is relatively simple, (you can move, open menus/your inventory, attack, and do aimed attacks) the combat system is extremely good, and also incredibly satisfying, especially when it goes your way. Probably one of the best I've ever experienced in a cRPG, in fact. The combat does exactly what it is supposed to do and does it very well, and can even be exploited by players that were careful with their character's build to get great benefits, like being able to get immense criticals by aiming at specific enemy body parts (Rat was critically hit in the eyes for 666 hit points, blinding the unlucky creature. Rat was killed.) or being able to attack more times per turn by stacking AP properly. Fallout encourages powergaming heavily, and greatly rewards players that are experienced in the game.
Fallout's combat is not without its flaws, however. There is at times a frustratingly heavy emphasis on RNG, the best example of which being how the player's chance to hit is always capped at 95%, regardless of their skill in the weapon/other factors. This leaves a window for the player to be able to miss, no matter how ridiculous the circumstances. There is also a rather obscure critical failure mechanic, where if your skill in something is too low (or even if it's high enough) you'll ♥♥♥♥ up on that specific action so hard that you'll break what you're trying to do. Sometimes in combat you'll lose a turn or even break your weapon. While this mechanic was probably meant to make the gameplay more dynamic, it only truly results in making it more frustrating for players, and usually leads to players saving exceedingly often to pad themselves against the game's inherent unpredictability.
The game is relatively short by RPG standards, usually lasting around 20-30 hours for most (non-completionist) players, but has an enormous amount of content. While a skilled and dedicated player can beat the game in under an hour if they wish to, there is nothing stopping you from tackling on Fallout's great many side-quests and encounters. There is a heavy emphasis in this game on quality over quality, and it shows, as every event in the game is unique and there is pretty much no copy-pasted filler content.
All in all, Fallout is an iconic RPG, in great part shaping both the genres of modern post-apocalyptic fiction, and that of role-playing games, and is heavily befitting of being called a true classic. If you consider yourself a fan of role-playing games and haven't played this, you seriously need to. If you consider yourself a fan of Fallout games and haven't played this, you seriously need to get out.

The darkness of the afterlife is all that awaits you now. May you find more peace in that world than you found in this one...

reviewText:
After replaying this game after about 4-5 years, I have to say it is one of the greatest RPGs ever made. The Fallout universe is so rich and enticing. A lot of people worry they will dislike this game to today's standards because of it's bird's-eye/perspective view, but the story, dialouge, soundtrack, locations, factions and NPCs all come together so well. It is a game you really should not miss out on. If you love the newer Fallout's you should really come back to where it all started.

There is so many different character builds you can make to suit your style. It has a solid combat system and level progression feels nice. You truly feel your character get stronger as you increase your level, improve your stats and get new gear.

As you progress through the world of Fallout the way you go about your quests truly effects the world. This also effects the end game, as it shows you how you've effected the world and there is many varying endings.

Overall this is a fantastic game, if you love Fallout, RPGs, tactical RPGs, stratergy games (To some extent) and games that are story driven, Fallout has it all! 10/10

reviewText:
It is a somewhat pointless attempt for me to write a review of the first installment of the Fallout series, because I LOVE IT SO MUCH. I have to admit, that I'm a sort of a fanboy of this game (and for some extent of its sequel Fallout 2). This might be my all time favourite video game. I absolutely fell in love with it back in 1997.

I love the 50s inspired retrofuturistic post-apocalyptic RPG setting. I love the character and combat systems. The overall graphics and especially the brutal ultra-violent death animations still please me. I absolutely love Mark Morgan's ambient soundtrack that reminds me of Aphex Twin's album Selected Ambient Works Volume II". The player can approach quests multiple ways depending on the character stats. The consequences of player's actions affect the whole Wasteland. The choices really feel like they matter. This truly feels like playing a RPG.

I admit there are some major technical limitations and some frustrating stuff throughout the game (Thanks Ian

reviewText:
Note: Do not attempt to play this if you have played Fallout 3, 4, and New Vegas first! Do some research before buying Fallout 1.

Where do i begin? You know it is amazing to see how far the Fallout series has gotten. And to think it started out like this. Most Fallout gamers will come to believe it's like the ones you see now.....it isn't. Not even close. Sure it has everything that makes Fallout very well known. But it plays extremely different. The game is two things. Turn based, and RPG. Turn base only happens during combat sequences and the RPG mechanics are completely everywhere. From the Character creation" when you first start it. To the dialouge and choices you make throughout Fallout 1.

This game is filled with content and lore that will make your head spin....or to make you rage quit at certain moments. It is best to save often because you will be needing it.....a lot. The skills and SPECIAL sort of works like what you see now. But it handles it a bit differently. My advice
date: is to do some research on the skills in Fallout 1 and how they work
recommended:
same goes with SPECIAL.

The only negative thing i could say about Fallout 1. Is mainly the Action Point system it's your everything during combat sequences from going into your inventory to choosing between vats mode and what i call "shootout mode" (Regular combat).

I could've mentioned the story but it's best if you do the research first before buying like i noted in the "note" section above. Other than that if you want a blast from the past this game is for you."

reviewText: The very first game of the series that spawned a great franchise. In Fallout, you play as a vault dweller who must save his vault from dying by getting a new water chip. However, you find out that there's more to saving the vault than just a water chip. The game is an isometric turn-based RPG and requires you to use various skills to progress through the game, such as picking locks on doors, bartering with NPC's and taking out various enemies with a wide array of arsenals. This game is nearly perfect, would recommend to anyone that wants to play an older, more challenging RPG games.

reviewText:
This is downright my favorite RPG ever made, but you gotta keep in mind, this game came out in 1997 and all I was doing at that point was ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ my diapers, I have no nostalgic sentiment for this game and it was in no way colored by idealized childhood memories. When I was younger, my favorite RPGs were KotOR and its sequel, and I sank like 1000 hours in both I'm sure. So I do have nostalgia out the ♥♥♥ for those games and I do have idealized memories. I played FO1 for the first time in the 2010s, and the experience is so good it stands up to and even towers over the RPGs I loved as a kid. Nostalgia is a powerful force and if you can beat that, that's a really good sign.

The port job here is actually one of the few times I can say the Steam version of an old game is a completely tolerable  version, as Bethesda has come in and spruced up the game with some updates, most importantly adding the ability to use widescreen resolutions. The game runs pretty much fine, and the only real issue I can remember is it may rarely crash, and if you alt tab, the screen will be black but it has this weird thing where you uncover the screen by moving the mouse? I fonud that bringing up the pip boy or skills menu was a quick way to fix that.

And the game is excellent, the theming is incredible, the art design is old but holds up amazingly well to the point that the gore in this game will still make you go OH ♥♥♥♥ THO". It's an amazingly tight experience

reviewText:
Brown. Brown Never Changes. - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Incredibly dark, gritty games are very bountiful these days. Almost everything is trying to be THAT game. You know the one. More shades of brown than the cast of a black sitcom. Everything's gotta be super dark and serious. This is war, man. There's gotta be lots of blood and explosions, and brown. This is serious. People die, man. Death is real. It's coming for you.

It wasn't always this way though. It used to be different. It used to be a happier, more peaceful gaming landscape. Sure, there were serious games. There were games with blood, games with death, and games with brown.

Super Mario wears brown shoes.

But you kids that are always ♥♥♥♥♥ing about not having enough color in games and all games being too dark, you don't know. It used to be something special. It used to be a unique art direction. At least until everyone jumped on the bandwagon and completely ♥♥♥♥ all over it. There was an original brown game. A game that said, hey, you know the color brown? Well guess what, it's everywhere. And it was a pleasant surprise.

The original is still by far one of the bests. It's got the unique art direction, the atmosphere, and it's charming in its own special way. In a sort of, giving a Get Well balloon to roadkill kind of way.

Fallout is the original grit. Fallout is the original brown. Brown before brown. Rocks and sand before rocks and sand. The first Fallout. Way back in 1997. Surprise, the Fallout series did not start on 3. There was a first game.

Fallout is a truly spectacular game. A marvel of classic RPG's, and arguably better than some modern RPG's in what it offers. Fallout is an open-world, turn-based tactical RPG. Set in an alternate future where Donald Trump became president and everything went to hell, you must set off from the safety of your underground vault to repair the satellite so grandma can watch Spongebob again. She gets cranky if she can't watch Spongebob.

There's a pretty large emphasis on you as the character. There are a few pre-made characters to choose from in case you don't know how to choose your stats properly, but it's best if you make your own. Using the S.P.E.C.I.A.L." system

reviewText:
My Personal Score: 3/5PCGamingWiki Page[pcgamingwiki.com]
Issues: none experienced during playthroughs.

Fallout is one of those classic games that never ceases to charm me everytime I play it. Being the root title in the behemoth of a franchise that it has become, there's nothing quite like exploring a post-apocalyptic Southern California in an isometric view and role-playing with Interplay's primordial SPECIAL system which still offers a unique gameplay experience despite its age. It's going to be jarring to play this game coming from the 3D sequels what with the lack of explanations for the mechanics and skill checks at every turn ala pen and paper RPGs but if you take the time to learn all of its intricacies and having the mindset to play a game like this, you'll be rewarded with a one-of-a-kind experience that only old school RPGs could offer.


And there you have it.

reviewText:
Fallout is probably one of the most immersive RPG's I've ever played in my entire experience with gaming. For this review I'll divide it into categories of the game and discuss the Pros and Cons".

Gameplay Mechanics
Fallout's gameplay is entirely dependant on the character that you create. This can vary based on the perks and skills you pick up as you progress through the game. The stats of this game are "what make you  S.P.E.C.I.A.L ". Strength
voteText: Intelligence
helpfulPercent: Agility and Luck. Strength affects your overall carry weight and melee damage. Perception allows you to have more dialogue options
votesHelpful: higher ranged accuracy and the distance in which you encounter random hostilities. Endurance modifies your health
votesTotal: resistance to poison/radiation
votesFunny: healing rate and hit points recieved upon leveling up. Charisma is what affects player interaction between NPC's. This stat will give the player the ability to barter more efficiantly and open up dialogue options. Intelligence allows the player to recieve more skill points upon leveling up
commentsCount: more dialogue options and skills. One thing I should also mention is that characters with very low intelligence are very funny to play as. I reccomend doing so if you want a good laugh. Agility allows the player to have more action points in combat and move faster in game. Lastly
column16: Luck grants players bonuses to accuracy
column17: critical damage chance and the gambling skill of the player. Perks also affect your character to further shape what you ideally want. For example
column18: the perk "Small Frame" will give your character enhanced speed and more action points at the cost of strength.\n\nCombat in Fallout 1 is turn based. The amount of moves a player has is dependant on action points. Swift characters may have more action points
column19: but could deal little to no damage if that is the only invested skill. Slow
column20: but heavy characters can dish out loads of damage and possibly tank enemies to give companions opportunities of attacking
column21: but can rarely move due to an undeveloped Agility skill. Combat is entirely dependant on what you want (like stated earlier). The various ways it can be shapen into is what gives this game replayability.\n\nVarious skills such as Barter
column25: First Aid are the factors that also affect combat. For example
column26:
if the player creates a merchant character (someone with high Charisma and Barter) then that player can profit off of NPC's and have access to numerous buffs and expensive items. Characters with high Sneak and Big Guns make great Snipers that pick off enemies and assist companions.

Story
You play as the Vault Dweller of Vault 13. The Overseer calls you as he needs your assistance in saving the vault. The water purification chip that provides drinking water to the Vault inhabitants is broken. He asks if you can adventure deep into the wasteland to bring back a waterchip and save the Vault. The player is only given 150 days to do so. This is the only information I feel is necessary to give as Fallout 1's story should really be experienced hands on. The only thing I will also mention is that the story will evolve into something more elaborate as you progress. Please
column27: experience it for yourself. It becomes very philosophical.\n\nImmersive Factors: Music
column29: etc.\nFallout 1 has an amazing soundtrack. It sets the tone of a dark
column30: morbid post apocalyptic world. It embodies the wasteland that Western America has become. The hatred
column31: emptiness and agony of the people that survived the nuclear destruction is captivated in this soundtrack. Like I said before
column32: experience this for yourself. All I can do is praise it.\n\nThe setting of this game takes place in the west coast of America. Due to the Great War sand and radiation is all that's left in the world. Throughout the game
column35: caves and cults. They're well made artistically and the music compliments them well.\n\nThe people of Fallout will vary morally. The characters of this game juxtapose nicely as many of them have different interests. You have people seeking to bring justice and law to the wasteland
column36:
greedy and power hungry individuals that only care about their self benefit and an elitest group that I do not want to spoil.

Overall Rating
If you're a fan of RPG's then purchase this game immediately. I can say with utmost certainty that you will enjoy this game. You will be kept immersed and entertained. Let this game also prove that modern graphics aren't what make a game. This was released in 1997 and to this day it still has an incredibly large following."

reviewText:

Basically, Fallout excells in the fundamental mechanics of an RPG.

If you haven't played through this game from start to finish, you're missing out.

reviewText: War, war never changes...\nAn amazing game that stands up to the test of time. This is one of the best roleplaying games out there. It came as close as possible to being a pen-and-paper experience - with the ability to craft your own character the way you *want*, without choices being forced on the player. There are a few quirks in the system, and it's certainly not as big as the sequel, but the non-linearity, interesting plot and backstory make up for it. Try this game as soon as possible - you won't be disappointed.

reviewText:
However controversial it can be at times, it’s more than apparent that Fallout is a game that was made with a lot of love and I can tell you that more than fifteen years on it still shows.
Here is one of the most fondly loved titles that developer Black Isle ever put out (the other being Planescape Torment), Fallout is a role playing game set in a post apocalyptic United States seeped in Fifties retro futurism and Cold War Americana.

With its rather drab palette of colours, eerie ambient music and simplistic combat, you’d think Fallout to be a false prophet at first glance but that’s before you’ve experienced the writing.

Every NPC you chat with and almost every action you take in-game is accompanied by strings of incredibly well written text that develop the game’s setting much further than its meager appearance would might usually allow.

This is a one-of-a-kind series that redefines what a mature and well written RPG really is.

Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

reviewText:
Here's a recap of my first half-hour on one of my playthroughs.

I created a character and named him Beowulf, and I poured all my points into maxing out his Strength and Agility.

I then decided to NOT equip the Brass Knuckles, in favor of beating the hell out of everything with my bare hands - in true Beowulf fashion.

I then proceded to use this method to kill every rat in the cave, then went to Vault 15 and killed everything there.

After that, I went back to Shady Sands, went to the RadScorpion Cave, and punched a RadScorpion so hard in the brain that I knocked it senseless, pacified it, and ended the combat with it still alive.

I then walked over to it and ripped its tail off, still breathing.



I have since then added a dog and a couple gun-toting thugs to my posse, and have saved a girl from a gang of Raiders by fighting their leader in bare-handed combat (won with hardly a scratch), then went and killed all of his subordinates for kicks.

GOD DAMN, it feels good to be Beowulf.

reviewText:
Fallout 1 is an old game. It held up decently though.

You get sent out form your little hole in the ground community to get a new water chip. Because it's a wasteland full of hardened criminals and raiders - and you're the one that's less likely to get killed if you go into the world with merely a rusty knife (seriously a gun would have made more sense but I guess gaming rules have to go the route of Start with nothing and work your way up").

As this game's lore goes somewhere in the 1950s the apocolypse happened. The details are pretty unimportant as the war is something that's from a time no one cares about anymore. It was at least a generation or two ago. But the results of it lasted: a wasteland covering the entire world as far as most around can tell.

One of the first things I discovered in this was it's very eager and able to kick your ♥♥♥. Sometimes simply walking into a public area is enough for the whole place to kil you. if you die you die perminently. if your party members die they die perminently. There's no revive in any sense of the word for this game. And it takes almost no time at all before any ally you get dies if you aren't abusing saves to redo every fight they died in. It wasn't until I managed to get ahold of Power Armor when I started feeling somewhat badass.

It's possible that I am to blame though what with having prioritized non combat skills such as bartering and speach. I garuntee you'll never have any money issues if you put heavy amounts into bartering and charisma. When you start reaching 90% shops start paying you more than you pay them. So you can actually keep trading the same items between each other and just have them pay some caps on top of that - effectively walking away with the entire store for free if you wanted to.

The AI in Fallout 1 is pretty terrible. If it's not simply blocking your way so you can't walk through a door for 2-3 minutes straight (and oh does it ever do that a lot) it's jumping in front of you in combat or worse burst firing so it'll kill everyone in front of it - often other party members and yourself. 40% of this game's difficulty comes from the party you babysit. The party doesn't level up with you so they quickly become flat out obsolete. With little to no personality or story surrounding them you really won't feel bad just giving up and letting them die when they die. They're practically faceless. I did find it pretty cool you could have multiple followers though. It actually felt like a party of travelers... until it became babysitting anyway. they lose their appeal when a single super mutant kills all of them with a single attack in your general direction.

The turn based top-down combat was not what I expected when I started playing. It was honestly pretty good once the followers weren't involved though.

This game suffered from lacking in explaination for the interface. There were some things that were vital to know - such as how to set traps or disable them
date:
how to use stimpacks or how to use items on the environment (which left me stuck near the end of the game as I didn't know how to hook up a radio to a computer until I looked up help online).

It also suffered from some nonsense errors throughout the game - such as trying to operate a switch to open a door and getting a "no space in inventory" response.

Also deathclaws are hell. I have to point them out because ♥♥♥♥ deathclaws. The only way they could be harder is if when you killed them a second one popped out of the carcass of the first - wearing power armor and holding a minigun. And instead of bullets it shot more deathclaws out from it.

It's a good game. By today's standards I'd give it a 6/10 realistically

reviewText:
I played enough already to tell you that this game is a masterpiece and probably every oldschool gamers will tell you the same thing.

Being a dystopia of the 50's in a post-nuclear war environment flooded with radiations, mutants and survivors.
Fallout is much more open in its variety of choices and possibilities than, for example, Diablo 1 which came a year before.

-You can Talk to almost every NPCs with multiple dialogue choices which will grant or deny you some ways to deal with problems.
-Not a talker? Kill anyone in sight if you want! Pew pew pew! Takatakatak!
A large variety of weapons can be found in the wasteland.
-To be (A thief) or not to be? Pick any pocket in sight to get ammo, money, etc!
-7 SPECIAL abilities such as :
Strengh, Intelligence, Charisma, Luck...
-18 skills such as :
Small/Big Guns, Lockpick, Steal, Science, Speech...
-53 perks such as :
Animal Friend, Flower Child, Explorer, Fortune Finder...
-Choose 2 personal traits between 16 choices such as :
Bloody Mess, Good Natured, Jinxed, Skilled, Kamikaze...
-You can take drugs and booze to boost your SPECIAL and Skills
(WARNING : May cause addiction)
-You can roam the wasteland freely without any limitations but the map borders.
-The gunplay and combats are turned based. I think it's perfect because it's probably the only gameplay possible to deal with the way guns works in it.

A real-time f**k-fest of bullets would be insane and unplayable.

The wanted realism gives a survival side and your health is a part of it.
It's not like in Diablo where you can boost your life, use magic and surealist stuff.

After playing more or less 1000h hours on Fallout 3, I can finaly say that Bethesda did a great job to reenact the awesomeness of the Fallout series.

May the power of atom be with you wastelanders!

reviewText: Perhaps the strongest aspect of Fallout is that it is ideal for RPG newbies yet at the same time provides a depth of role-playing that veterans can really get stuck into. It also has the best replay value of any game I've experienced to date.The game play is smooth, using action points for movement and combat and the inventory system is easily managed. Fallout has one of the best character development systems of any computerized role-playing game and the graphics and story make for an excellent gaming experience.For anyone with an interest in complex, combat-heavy, lovingly produced RPGs Fallout is a must buy. In an age where many are predicting the death of traditional RPGs at the hands of multiplayer extravaganzas, Fallout is a glowing example of the genre, one which positively radiates quality. Fallout – it's da bomb.

reviewText:
if you dont like older games or slow gameplay than i would advise not buying this game, however for being as old as it is, this title as aged quite well. even the graphics for the combat,areas,and characters are muddy at best, the overall story and feel of adventure you get when traverising the wastes is enough to keep you wrapped up for several hours of gameplay. one of the major flaws however is that it is quite buggy, for instince, i once had a broken arm so i was unable to fire two handed weapons but the game wouldnt let my character or any of the in game doctors fix it.
As i stated before the combat is slow but very involving and strategical, if youve ever played any x-com games than you will understand the mechanics exaclty. this allows the game to make situations more tense and difficult forcing to do more than just charging in and blasting dudes in the face, but is not such a bad thing. when you have to slow down and analyze scenarios, the combat is more involving and satisfying, because unlike other games where you can just shoot this random dude in the face, you can hide and set up explosives to blow his legs off, run up, and then shoot him.
one major drawback to the gameplay though is the fact that there is a time limit of 400-500 in game days before you lose the game, so its something like dead rising 2's sand box, where you can goo off and have fun just dont expect a happy ending. also the display screen for your weapons and perks could be a bit more descriptive, but considering the pace games where at that time were at i'll let that one pass.
the last thing i wamt to talk about is the plot whic is actually pretty original considering the setting being completely cliche( post-apcolyptic america). you are a resident of one of the many vaults that protected a select few but one day the water chip begins to go down and you are chosen to brave the wastes and retrieve another. in your adventures you come across such things as crashed aliens, dr. who, deathclaws, giant master race mutats, raiders, and shotgun wileding robo-brains. you must battle all of these and more as you search for your vault's salvation. like i said pretty original.

So all in all it may be old and have some minor faults its still a pretty solid, and one of the best rpgs of all time. if you like turnbased combat, awesome storytelling,and hours of fun then this game is for you. i would rate it 9/10.

reviewText: I'll admit, I played this after Fallout 3 and New Vegas so was initially turned off by the style of this game. It's an isometric turn-based RPG. I gave it a shot because I find the Fallout universe so very intruiging. At first I didn't like this game at all. The lack of a tutorial hurt the game a bit and the instructions are very unspecific. But I realized that's the beauty of the game: figuring ♥♥♥♥ out for yourself. There's a lot of depth to the exploration and dialogue. You need to piece it together yourself and explore to find your next objective. The only point where this backfires is after the water chip part. You are given literally nothing to go on after that whereas the rest of the game offers at least some clues. As for the combat, this starts out pretty bad too. You start off with the worst accuracy for every weapon. That gets better but it takes a while to get somewhere with weapons. Once you increase your stats high enough the combat gets intense, challenging, and extremely rewarding. The story is decent. But the characters and locations (Boneyard, Catherdral) are really interesting and fun to explore. Soundtrack and sound effects are awesome too. Lastly, the atmosphere. Probably the best in any game ever.\n\n90/100 - The only reason this isn't a perfect score is because of the very slow start, lack of a tutorial, and after the water chip bit.

reviewText:
Fallout is possibly the first game to have a wide variety of choices and consequences. (and perks/traits.) And it shouldn't be played just because it's the first to do it, but because it does it very well.

It starts with a simple premise: You live in an underground nuclear fallout shelter (aka, a Vault) 80 years after a two-hour war between China and the US basically ended up in the both countries getting wholly nuked, and the water chip that keeps a supply of water to the whole Vault was damaged, and you were the unlucky one to have to venture out into the outside world to find the closest Vault and get another chip to save everyone you know. You are expelled into a cave full of rats (the ultimate and classic RPG enemy) and have to venture out, the first of your Vault to do so.

Fallout's system, SPECIAL, was made in a week (with the exception of perks), and it shows. The original goal of the team, when the game still had a license for GURPS (another system) was that no skill or stat should be useless. Well, first tip to creating a character: dump Charisma and get 4 free stat points. There are also a lot of mostly useless skills, but anyone with half a brain should distinguish the useless from the useful.

Combat is nothing special, except for the gory death animations: When getting crits with different weapons, enemies (or you) will die in very elaborate deaths: getting cut in half by the sheer amount of bullet holes a burst fire of a mini-gun has gave you, for example! It's pretty fun, even though the combat itself lacks tactical depth (sure, you can aim at limbs, eyes and crotch, but you'll end up shooting eyes always - well, maybe crotch for some amusing banter :))

It's not a very long game, but throughout it you venture through several settlements that have been built   by the surivivors of California. You will have several multi-pathed quests and consequences, though, sadly, most of the consequences are only showed in the slideshow at the end of the game. Still, you will feel that your choices matter.

The atmosphere is great, with no small influence of the great ambient soundtrack Mark Morgan produced, and the game gets better the more you progress into it: The final two areas have the most different ways of approaching the obstacles presented, and the game ends with one of the best ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ final bosses" of game history

reviewText: Great game, especially for fans of the newer titles. If you're a fan of Fallout 3/NV or like old-school RPGs, play the first two Fallout games. Though the functionalities of an older game such as this do take a little bit of getting used to, once you get the hang of it it becomes a rich, very fun experience that is surprisingly similar to what you get in the newer titles. It's actually surprising to see just how much Bethesda got right when translating Fallout 3 into an updated 3D version of the same universe. And although there are some (not uncommon to modern Fallout) glitchy elements which definitely got smoothened out in the second installment, the original Fallout is a fun play even to this day, with an amazing story, hours of gameplay, funny moments, and some good 'ol turn-based combat that features some of the most gruesome and entertaining death scenes I've ever seen.

reviewText:
Fallout was 1997’s best role-playing game. It was released in a time where people had been waiting years for something really groundbreaking to come by in an RPG, and Interplay didn’t miss the mark.

In order to survive a great nuclear war in this futuristic game, the survivors of humanity sought shelter in underground vaults to escape the nuclear fallout (hence the title). The character is in one such vault, but escaping the wastelands is not the only problem. This vault’s water-recycling chip has malfunctioned and the leader of the community is asking the player’s character to go to a neighboring vault for a replacement. If only a journey in the wasteland were simple.

Players find that there are communities on the surface, and they’re scraping the bottom trying to survive just like those below. Gangs that resemble something from the Mad Max series roam the wasteland preying on those struggling to make a living. Some people have undergone transformations; so have some animals. Finding a water chip or other suitable drinking water is not going to be an easy task.

The game system takes some time to get used to, but not so much that it detracts from the enjoyment of the game. Mostly a mouse-driven game, players have cursor options to select actions, conditions, and manage inventory. Taking care of said inventory isn’t a comfortable process, as players are forced to manage all loot in a single columned interface.

Fallout does some things quite well. Character creation is quite thorough, including optional traits and perks to enhance characters’ starting abilities, making him/her unique. Fallout’s creators also attempted to implement a system of “right and wrong,” and player interaction with NPCs is affected by Karma. As two more examples, sound and music both compliment the story environment without going over the top.

Like games of the time, there are some things that greatly under-perform. Most roaming NPCs are fairly useless for more than a grunt, snide remark, or comic relief. While players can recruit companions, they have no control over them, allowing for situations where the recruits will shoot players (and other NPC companions) in the back or block the path. They do not target what the player targets most of the time, and players will notice when trying to do something nefarious that combat will provoke NPCs to target other people, including children, which just cause one’s Karma to bust. Also, players’re forced to trade with them to provide them any resources. They don’t wear armor or gain levels making them weak and pathetic in the end-game.

The presentation of the story is both humorous and enlightening. The previously touched-on story is set in the future, but most everything looks like it came out not long after World War II. What’s left of civilization is surviving under the tow of two-headed cows while rusting autos and modern technologies similar to our era are strune about. Bottle caps are the currency of choice and iguana sticks are to die for.

All things being said, Fallout is still one of the best RPGs ever made for the PC and sparked a great trend. It is true that it came out around the same time Blizzard released Diablo, but Fallout breaks the mold.

Mostly a mouse-driven game, players have cursor options to select actions, conditions, and manage inventory. Taking care of said inventory isn’t a comfortable process, as players are forced to manage all loot in a single columned interface.

Fallout does some things quite well. Character creation is quite thorough, including optional traits and perks to enhance characters’ starting abilities, making him/her unique. Fallout’s creators also attempted to implement a system of “right and wrong,” and player interaction with NPCs is affected by Karma. As two more examples, sound and music both compliment the story environment without going over the top.

Like games of the time, there are some things that greatly under-perform. Most roaming NPCs are fairly useless for more than a grunt, snide remark, or comic relief. While players can recruit companions, they have no control over them, allowing for situations where the recruits will shoot players (and other NPC companions) in the back or block the path. They do not target what the player targets most of the time, and players will notice when trying to do something nefarious that combat will provoke NPCs to target other people, including children, which just cause one’s Karma to bust. Also, players’re forced to trade with them to provide them any resources. They don’t wear armor or gain levels making them weak and pathetic in the end-game.

The presentation of the story is both humorous and enlightening. The previously touched-on story is set in the future, but most everything looks like it came out not long after World War II. What’s left of civilization is surviving under the tow of two-headed cows while rusting autos and modern technologies similar to our era are strune about. Bottle caps are the currency of choice and iguana sticks are to die for.

All things being said, Fallout is still one of the best RPGs ever made for the PC and sparked a great trend. It is true that it came out around the same time Blizzard released Diablo, but Fallout breaks the mold.

reviewText:
One of the few games I recommend without hesitation.  Fallout 3 (a.k.a.: Oblivion 2) is total garbage, which completely lacks the mechanical equality, spirit, aesthetics and depth of its predecessors.  Fallout 3 is an open-world FPS that lacks the integral granularity to exist a an RPG, yet passes itself off as one as effectively as Steve Buscemi in drag.

The REAL Fallout series represents an almost unparallelled RPG system in its complexity, balance and replayability.  Fallout is, without hyperbole, also one of the most influential games in history; it literally is the foundation for much of the modern PC (and PnP) RPG paradigm.

Out of all the hundreds of RPGs I've played, Fallout 1&2 are still unquestionably in my top 5.

reviewText:
As franchises expand with every new release, thoughts of the previous entires come to mind. With the release of Fallout 4, I felt that it would be fun to replay the game that started it all. Released in 1997, Fallout was a hit and even now playing it 18 years after its release; it essentially holds up.

While the last 3 entries are very first person orientated with more frenetic action then the others; the original fallout is a 3rd person isometic turn based rpg that still offers an open world and an enriched story. The character creation is essentially the same as you distribute points in the S.P.E.C.I.A.L system as well as choosing skills and a few perks of choose from a few premade characters.

The base story seems very reminicent of Fallout 3, and like it once you leave the vault can do as you please. However, the game appears to be time sensitive and while I have no clue as to the consequences of failing have come across many sidequests in addition to the random encounters exploreing the map.

One thing I do want to stress is that unlike modern games; the user interface has a somewhat steep learning curve. By that, I mean asside from saving, you must manually reload weapons, and items are only used once at time. Bartering ( which later games simply became shops ) is broken down as placing items you don't want into the middle which will provide a cap value and then you choose items from the other party equal to or less of the value. ( Cap item limits max at 999. so if your trade was 1500 caps you would move 999 caps from other party and then additional 501 caps. NOTE: you can use the numeric keys for the value )

Overall, Its been a blast to play this game; and while very slow paced I cant help but appreciate the amount of content here in a game nearly 20 years old. If you a fan of the Fallout franchise, you owe it to yourself to give this game a chance and I would recommend anyone on the fence to checkout out some youtube videos of the gameplay. Its regularly 9.99 but during any number of steam sales is probably 4.99 or under.

If you found this review helpful or opinions of what could improve my next review, please  feel free to send me a message.

reviewText:
Pros:
Fallout is one of my favorite gaming worlds. It perfectly blends retro-futurism, post-apocalyptic     surivival, and dark humor to create a very unique universe that is fun to explore.
Your character matters: How you build your character and the choices you make really do change the story much more than in your typical RPG.
I love turn-based combat. While a little rough around the edges it still holds up.
The game focuses on your character. While you can get companions the story revolves around you and I really prefer this to having to manage an entire team of characters as I find it more immersive and am better able to role-play.Cons:
There are bugs. They shouldn't stop you from enjoying the game and there are fan-patches you can get that improve the game.
By today's standards the game can feel a little directionless. Try to embrace it but if you get stuck or lost you can always find a guide online.
The combat AI can be frustrating. For example, if you give a companion an automatic weapon they are just as likely to end up killing you as they are to kill your enemies. There are work arounds of course but it would be nice if the combat was a little smoother.Bottom line, Fallout is truly a classic that spawned a huge franchise. If you've never played it you really should give it a shot.
