reviewText:
What to say about this game? Well, for starters, it's a stepping stone to possibly one of the greatest game series of all time,  the Fallout series (Obviously), you may be more akin to Fallout 3 and New Vegas, but both Fallout 1 and 2 are an entire different breed of game altogether.
The game starts off in a Vault, Vault 13 to be more specific. A water chip, that keeps the Vault's water supply clean, but then all of a sudden, it breaks. The Overseer, sends out YOU to find a new Water Chip, setting in motion the Fallout series.
This game is not totally freely explorable like New Vegas or Fallout 3, it's timed, so you don't want to spend too much time in one place, it take's 150 days to find the Water Chip, which will be marked on your Pip Boy (Not a wrist pad in this version, but rather a small device), the game explains the origins of the NCR, and Super Mutants, and other places.
The combat is turn based, not first person, so you're going to have to take individual turns with you and your enemy when attacking, (I.E You attack first, but only for a certain number of times, the enemy attacks after, with the same set of rules.).
The plot can be changed, but there is a canon ending which i will not spoil, you should play it for yourself and see what you do to effect the games endings. You can check out guides and other stuff to help you along your way.
Overall, it's a excellent game, not meant for everyone though, the time limit can limit your experience wether you want to do side quests or not, and the combat can be a little too tough aswell.
But i recommend it, make sure you play this if you want the full Fallout experience (Along with Fallout 2 of course.)

Fallout never gets old as you can make fresh new characters and witness the different outcomes that can occur in game. A true classic from the past.

reviewText:
A great Role Playing Game.  There are multiple ways to play this game.  You can be a bit of a diplomat, talking your way through the game.  You can use fire power to blast away most enemies.  Or you can look for a different approach, like finding an important computer and activating the self-destruct sequence of a place and leaving.
This is an older game, so don't expect great looking character models.
Characters you find and add to your group can also be a pain in the butt at times.  They may fire at an enemy behind you, only to hit you instead.  Or they may block a door way and you have to wait for them to move.
I did run into some gameplay issue with the more update version of the game, causing the game to crash.  I had to load up the older version to get around this.  Thankfully, this only happened in to areas of the game and did not ruin things (I was able to load up the updated version once I was past the area where the game would crash and would save there).
This game can be difficult at times, as things may look favorable for you only to see your enemy get a BS lucky shot on you and kill you.
Overall, I really like this game, especially the ending.  After years of playing Japanese Role Playing Games, I got kinda tired of seeing everyone live happily ever after endings.  This game ending is harsh.  More fitting for the world of Fallout and the landscape, the Wasteland.  If you do plan to play this game, I do hope you do NOT look up the ending on YouTube.  It would possible ruin the experience for you and the work you character does in the game.

reviewText:
How it All BeganThis is the original Fallout, complete with original graphics, blemishes and virtues. There is an incredible amount of depth to the world that you can inhabit. Time to go 'in depth' for my new review style.

Gameplay
Fallout 1 is an isometric RPG. It is, obviously, a little archaic. There are several different mouse pointers you must constantly alternate between to either examine, move or fight things. The combat is simple yet satisfying, with enough weapons and different combat approaches to each encounter that it can stay fresh. Moving through the desert is a harrowing, luck-based affair, with a grid-styled map that you can move through showing the world. Places of importance are highlighted in green, and random encounters stop you on your journey to keep it fresh. Overall, Fallout has impressive gameplay that stands up to the tests of time.

Story
Your vault is running out of water. You are the last hope for your entire vault. This plot hook, though good, actually limits the game. A time limit is placed on you of 150 days, and if water is not obtained for your vault before the end of those 150 days, you will 'fail' the game. This places unnecessary pressure onto your shoulders, although it is incredibly effective at keeping players on the path of the main story. However, this leaves you with little opportunity to delve into other side missions or characters. Several characters will have to be made before you can experience everything.

Graphics and Atmosphere
Quite obviously the graphics are not going to be current-day good. Don't expect high quality graphics, and if you criticize the game for it's graphics... well then, what do you expect?
It's the atmosphere that really sells the game. A broken landscape with intriguing characters and it's own, unique brand of humour really sells the unique vibe of a civilization that never got out of the 50's, and then got nuked. It's very enjoyable just to explore, even if there is no music.

Summary
Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game is a game that is very much worth your time. With a low asking price and hours worth of fun, there's very little reason that you shouldn't pick up the first Fallout, especially at a time like now when the future of Fallout is coming... why not return to the past?

reviewText:
This game is legendarily great. The gameplay and story are compelling, but the world is the real star of the show here. That, and Harold and Dogmeat. They're stars too.

Tips for companions:

Dogmeat is a machine. Doesn't do much damage, but moves ridiculous distances, attacks 4 times a round, knocks enemies down all over the place so that you can 95% critical their eyes, and, most importantly, is the emotional heart of the story. I kept him alive all the way.

Tycho is great. He's smart, durable, and funny. Just keep him stocked with shotgun shells and Stimpaks and he'll never let you down. Unfortunately, he died in the Cathedral.

Ian is a staple for the first part of the game, but by the time you get power armor he's basically obsolete. I let him go eventually.

Katja can mark the Cathedral on your map. That's about it. I made the mistake of giving her an SMG, and eventually abandoned her along with Ian. Hopefully they're fine in the middle of the desert.

P.S. The gory death animations are fine, but the fact that they're used as rewards for winning makes them that much more priceless.

P.P.S. I accidentally dropped Vree's holodisk moments after getting it in the Brotherhood base, later realized how important it is, went back, and, months later, it was still there. The Brotherhood really needs a janitor.

reviewText: Where it all started, Fallout. Before Bethesda got the rights to the Fallout series and gave us the wonders of Fallout 3, New Vegas, and 4, Fallout was owned by Interplay and Black Isle studios. The classic Fallout games (1-tactics) were isometric turn based rpgs with a heavy open world exploration aspect to them. Now, jumping away from the history lesson and back to the game at hand. Fallout is a gritty, post apocolyptic rpg set after a nuclear war. And it really shows, raiders, super mutuants, anything in this wastland can be a friend or most likely a foe. The game can be very diffucult if you don't know what to expect. Everything you encounter, from cave rats to the brotherhood of steel, can kill you. Here's some spoilers, so don't touch if you don't want the story ruined. Ready? Alright.  You're tasked by the overseer of vault 13 to find a new water chip for the vault, as the one they have has died and water is running low. Setting off into a cave and the huge wastes, you must find a water chip and destroy the ever looming threat of the supermutant army, led by the Master. Once you complete these tasks in any order you please, you return to the vault you just saved....only to be banished.  If you're looking for a long, difficult at times, classic rpg, you should turn to the classic Fallout series. A definite must buy for any rpg fan.

reviewText:
So one day i bought FALLOUT  and i had already played 3 and new vegas before that, and i had no expirence with turn-based bird-view RPGS, so it was really hard to get into this game and i was almost to the point with saying F this game.
But i kept playing and now I F*****G LOVE THIS GAME <3 <3 <3 <3 <3.
So first of all the story:
So the story is quite simple you are from a working vault called Vault 13, but suddenly the Overseer(king of the vault)
says that we are running out of drinking water and he wants you to find them a waterchip to fix thier problem. The waterchip is used to fix up radiated water.
One thing i really love about this game is that you can complete all the main quests without any help or given locations.
Like for example one girl actually knows where to find the waterchip and it is in a place that you could get a holodisk to find or you could just travel around the wasteland until you find it.
another thing is that the water quest is actually timed so you have about 120 days to find it or else you loose the game!!

So now i will give  pros and cons about ths game
PROS
-gameplay that works
-great story
-pretty good graphics
- talking like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ with low intellgence skill
-TOO AWESOME
-can be played on pretty much any computer

-CONS

-no journal, what i mean by that is that i tried doing a quest for someone and he said something about go west then south when you find this place and then kill them, but i completely forgot where to go and he didn't mention it again so i either had to remember it or write down on a piece of paper, it's not a big deal but i didn't like it :(
-too short dunno man i just wanted more.

-MY OPINION i only thought this game was awesome when i had good guns and protection, but that's just me and not really a con but i had to mention it.

-No freeplay after main quests, this really sucks if you have unfinished side quests that play a big role but actually in the end the narroter tells about what happend to ceartain places if you didn't help them which is really cool ;D

SO overall i think that this is one  of the best RPGS ever made even though i'm not a hardocre RPG'r,
i will say that this is proabaly one of the best games that i ever played in my life, AND i cannot wait to play fallout 2 i'll just wait for a discount though.

reviewText: It is the year 2161, 84 years after nuclear war reduced the planet into a barren, desolate wasteland. Much of the surviving populations live in Vaults-self sustaining bunkers built shortly before the war. You are a member of Vault 13. One day, Vault 13's water purification chip breaks, and the Overseer is forced to send you out into the wasteland to find a new water chip. Have fun!

reviewText:
Let me begin by saying i have played every fallout game to date.
Fallout is a Open World Post Nuclear Role Playing Game, Which Is Set 80 Years after the Nuclear War which nearly brought an end to mankind there were a few lucky survivors who were able to enter these giant underground Vault's on the day that the bombs dropped, you were born in Vault 13.

The Main Story Plot of Fallout is that Your Vaults Water Purification Chip has Broken and that means that The Vault will run out of drinking water very soon so the Vault's Overseer Send's you the Vault Dweller out on a Quest to find a replacement Water Chip.

Gameplay in Fallout centers around the game world, visiting locations and interacting with the local inhabitants. Occasionally, inhabitants will be immersed in dilemmas which the player may choose to solve in order to acquire karma and experience points. Fallout deviates from most role-playing video games in that it often allows for the player to complete tasks in multiple ways, often choosing solutions that are unconventional or even contrary to the original task, in which case the player may still be rewarded. The player's actions may ultimately dictate the ending of the game, or what future story or gameplay opportunities are available. Ultimately, players will encounter hostile opponents (if such encounters are not avoided using stealth or diplomacy), in which case they and the player will engage in combat. Non-combat portions of the game are typically played in real-time.

Combat in Fallout is turn-based. The game uses an action point system wherein, each turn, multiple actions may be performed until all points in the pool have been expended. Different actions consume different numbers of points, and the maximum number of points that can be spent may be affected by such things as chems or perks. 'Melee' (hand to hand) weapons typically offer multiple attack types, such as 'Swing' and 'Thrust' for knives. Unarmed attacks offer many attack types, including 'Punch' and 'Kick'. Players may equip at most two weapons, and the player can switch between them by clicking a button. The Perception attribute determines characters' 'Sequence' number, which then determines the order of turns in combat; characters with a higher statistic in this attribute will be placed at an earlier position in the sequence of turns, and subsequently get new turns earlier. Perception also determines the maximum range of ranged weapons, and the chance to hit with them.

I Would Recomend Fallout To any fan of the Series Or Newcomer.
voteText: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
One of the best RPGs of all time.

The pacing is great, the plot is gripping, the dialogue is awesome (and often hilarious).

The graphics still hold up amazingly well for a now 17-year title and the sound effects are spot on. Music is subtle and atmospheric. Not memorable, but does a good job in seting the mood.

But what impresses me the most about this game is that it allows for both scripted experience and emergent experiences, as every situation can be remedied through a personally-selected mix of combat, stealth, dialogue.

While the game is not as much of a write-your-own as some other open-world games, it leans on the scripted content to create sequences & events that are truly awesome.

Good luck in the wastes!

reviewText:
Nostalgia levels over 9000!!!

This is the very first PC game I ever purchased. I still own my original disc copy, which is still in perfect condition. I recall in '97 going into my local PX and picking up the retail box from the shelf, and reading the description of the game on the back while deciding my future purchase. Had I known now how much I would come to love this series, I would have bought another copy to keep as a collector's item. Starting up my first game and hearing Ron Perlman's words; War. War never changes..." still sends chills up my spine to this very day. (By the way he still does the intro narrator voice for the series.)

The freedom of choosing your own way to advance in the game was different from most of which I had played at the time. The writing was witty and found my self laughing over some of the more hidden speech options. (Roll a character with a low INT
date: many LOLS to be had.) I found the combat enjoyable. You can target specific parts of the enemy's body
recommended: which allow you to cripple limbs and increasing critical damage. It may seem dated in appearance by today's standards
hoursPlayed: but makes up for that in quality story and plot. Now go get that water chip vault dweller. Vault 13 depends on you!\n\nTL:DR Version: Isometric view RPG with turn based tactical combat - Buy it

reviewText: Fallout is a classic post-apocolyptic RPG about a man (or woman, but canonically, a man) who must leave the safety of his underground vault after the bombs drop to smack a radscorpion in the face for some experience points.\n\nFallout 1 has aged well, despite what people tell you. Its a very fun experience, but pretty damn short (I finished my first playthrough in only 4 hours, with a guide). However, the game promotes multiple playthroughs since there is a large variety in the skills you have. You can pretty much play the game without ever having to kill people thanks to speech checks and all. This game doesn't really hold your hand though and it can sometimes be easy to get lost (and was one of the reasons I had to get a guide after a certain point). It can also throw you into a lot of situations where you just end up dying, so remember to save often. Fallout 2 is strictly the superior game as it boasts more content and length, but the first Fallout is still worth the play.

reviewText: Where it all started, Fallout. Before Bethesda got the rights to the Fallout series and gave us the wonders of Fallout 3, New Vegas, and 4, Fallout was owned by Interplay and Black Isle studios. The classic Fallout games (1-tactics) were isometric turn based rpgs with a heavy open world exploration aspect to them. Now, jumping away from the history lesson and back to the game at hand. Fallout is a gritty, post apocolyptic rpg set after a nuclear war. And it really shows, raiders, super mutuants, anything in this wastland can be a friend or most likely a foe. The game can be very diffucult if you don't know what to expect. Everything you encounter, from cave rats to the brotherhood of steel, can kill you. Here's some spoilers, so don't touch if you don't want the story ruined. Ready? Alright.  You're tasked by the overseer of vault 13 to find a new water chip for the vault, as the one they have has died and water is running low. Setting off into a cave and the huge wastes, you must find a water chip and destroy the ever looming threat of the supermutant army, led by the Master. Once you complete these tasks in any order you please, you return to the vault you just saved....only to be banished.  If you're looking for a long, difficult at times, classic rpg, you should turn to the classic Fallout series. A definite must buy for any rpg fan.

reviewText:
This pretty much sums up my opinion of the game. Yeah. That good.

1 cup all-purpose flour, (spooned and leveled)
2 tablespoons sugar
2 teaspoons baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
1 cup milk
2 tablespoons unsalted butter, melted, or vegetable oil
1 large egg
1 tablespoon vegetable oil
Assorted toppings, such as butter, maple syrup, confectioners' sugar, honey, jams, preserves, sweetened whipped cream, or chocolate syrup

Preheat oven to 200 degrees; have a baking sheet or heatproof platter ready to keep cooked pancakes warm in the oven. In a small bowl, whisk together flour, sugar, baking powder, and salt; set aside.
In a medium bowl, whisk together milk, butter (or oil), and egg. Add dry ingredients to milk mixture; whisk until just moistened (do not overmix; a few small lumps are fine).
Heat a large skillet (nonstick or cast-iron) or griddle over medium. Fold a sheet of paper towel in half, and moisten with oil; carefully rub skillet with oiled paper towel.
For each pancake, spoon 2 to 3 tablespoons of batter onto skillet, using the back of the spoon to spread batter into a round (you should be able to fit 2 to 3 in a large skillet).
Cook until surface of pancakes have some bubbles and a few have burst, 1 to 2 minutes. Flip carefully with a thin spatula, and cook until browned on the underside, 1 to 2 minutes more. Transfer to a baking sheet or platter; cover loosely with aluminum foil, and keep warm in oven. Continue with more oil and remaining batter. (You'll have 12 to 15 pancakes.) Serve warm, with desired toppings.

reviewText: The game that started one of the greatest RPG series, Fallout is a classic RPG experience that will take you into a post-nuclear universe as you explore an apocalyptic world and discover the ethics surrounding it; while providing an excellent story, well done RPG mechanics, fantastic turn-based gameplay, and a world that is affected by your very actions. Any fan of Fallout or RPGs in general must play this game.

reviewText:
+Great game, lotta fun once you figure out the combat system
+Learn a lot about the Fallout universe that you wouldn't know from only playing 3 or New Vegas, such as what happened at other Vaults, the origins of things like super-mutants and Raiders
+Awesome weapons
+Turn-based combat is tough and always keeps you on your toes
+Enemies are scarier as a result
+As far as I know, you can't become an invincible god like in 3 and New Vegas which gives you a sense of humility
+Which also forces you to fight cautiously, strategically and pick your battles
+Random events are either positive or negative so you're hopeful, yet cautious when traveling
+In-game time is important, which gives a sense of immersion
+In-game time isn't too fast or too slow, it's just right
+It also goes into much more vivid detail than most games, there's an in-game calendar and things happen on certain dates, most games do night/day like , occasionally you'll see a game that does time of the day or day of the week
+No fast traveling like in 3 or New Vegas. Instead of pulling up your Pip Boy and selecting a place, you have to actually leave your current city, then travel to the next. You're shown a map of the whole area and once you click somewhere, your guy moves as in-game time flies by at a realistic and believable pace. You also slow down at mountains and stuff, to make it seem more like you're climbing them. Occasionally, you get a random event which stops your traveling and gives you more of a feeling like your actually adventuring

-Combat system is hard to get used to
-Enemies can be a bit too tough at times
-If there are too many enemies, you're going to die, no matter how much skill or luck you possess
-If there are enough NPCs during a battle, you have to wait forever for your turn as each NPC moves and attacks one at a time, especially during missions where you help escort the Crimson Caravan
-During such battle, I bet I could walk away from my computer, make a sandwich, and come back and still be waiting for my turn
-Turn based combat is annoying and confusing before you learn how it works, which is not easy because it isn't self-explanatory in any way

+/- Even though it's Fallout, it has a completely different feel if you're like most Fallout players if you've only played 3 or New Vegas. I like this fact, but I can imagine that others wouldn't
+/- Neurtal NPCs react to you unholstering your weapon. From a realism point of view, it makes sense, but from a gameplay point of view, it can be annoying

reviewText:
For those of you who got this game after playing 3, New Vegas and/or 4, prepare for a whole different cup of tea.

This game is a isometric top down RPG(in case you didnt see the screenshots) and is a game that does not hold your hand whatsoever.

And this being an older Fallout game means.....

1) No tutorials and you are just thrown into the game straight.
2) No quest markers meaning you might bang your head trying to find the correct location.
3) You have to figure things out on your own.
4) You have to save frequently lest you lose progress.
5) Combat is significantly different that what you are used in future Fallouts, being slow and tactical.
6) Inventory management and bartering is more cumbersome.
7) Movement and exploration is slow with random encounters of random difficulty.

If any of those turn you off then I suggest you rethink your purchase. Other than that, the game has a compelling story, great characters and quests to take on, its pretty much what you expect from the Fallout games, you are tasked with a huge responsibility and you set out to explore the wasteland. Its a very good game for its time and if you can get over the old game tropes I listed above, you are gonna have a good time.

And look.....just be safe out there...ok.

reviewText:
“The struggle for survival is a war without end. And war… war never changes.”

Fallout is one of those rare role-playing games oozing quality from every pore – one might even say radiate. The gameplay is smooth, using action points for movement and combat. In addition it has one of the best character development systems you can wish for. The amazing story, great love for detail and high replayability make for an excellent gaming experience.

Fun fact: Fallouts retro-futurism has been inspired by 1950s pulp magazines, superhero comics of Atomic Age and classic Science Fiction films such as Forbidden Planet. There are also many references to the events and the style of Wasteland (PC game from 1988) in the Fallout series, which is why Fallout is sometimes regarded as a spiritual successor to Wasteland.
--

My rating system consists of six categories in descending order of importance:

-	Atmosphere
-	Characters
-	Details
-	Tactical gameplay
-	Story
-	Combat & Controls

Based on the performance each category will receive one of the following grading:

-	S-Rank: excellent
-	A-Rank: very good
-	B-Rank: solid
-	C-Rank: satisfactory
-	D-Rank: inferior

If the S-Rank is awarded, a quote from the game or personal comment will be added as a token of my respect (in brackets).
--

Atmosphere: S-Rank

(I am the bringer of death! Fall to your knees and beg for mercy… or give me a sandwich, I’m pretty hungry.)

Characters: S-Rank

(Do I have to sacrifice a puppy to join?)

Details: S-Rank

(To see a valley filled with my enemies’ heads mounted on spears. A silent valley, except for the wind whistling through their ears.)

Tactical gameplay: S-Rank

(Don’t drink glowing water.)

Story: S-Rank

(There is a bad place where the bad mutants come from. It is bad. Vault is good. Please, go and destroy bad place.)

Combat & Controls: S-Rank

(Excuse me while I gloat…)
--

There are no achievements to conquer.

Achievement difficulty: none
--

reviewText: Fallout is a fantastic game back in the day, but it is becoming pretty obvious that it did not age very well, to put it simply the gameplay and design is outdated. If you never had a knack to play ancient pc role-playing games, chances are pretty good you will not like Fallout. The control scheme is god awful compared to modern standards, and the repetitive textures are just visually boring. The gameplay is very standard for rpg game of the 90s. While Fallout may lack all the basic mechanics that makes modern games great, its storyline, environment, and sound will remain eternal. Fallout created a precedent for all great RPG’s to follow, the ability to shape the ending of the game started here. Much like its sequels, Fallout’s entire game world is flipping massive. Overall this game is in desperate need of a remake.

reviewText: Give the first game of this series a good try - even if it's surpassed by its more than splendid sequels. If you ignore a few annyoing bugs, some unfair battles and and the obsolete inventory/item management you'll experience an ~15 hours long trip like you've seldomly seen before in any other video game. Atmosphere, music, freedom of choices and the character development system stood the test of time and already cult - and even the isometric graphics have their very own charm.\n\nA tear of joy will definitely roll down your cheek when you finally defeat the obscure «Master» at the end of the game - how you do that is completely up to you.

reviewText:
Now that we have the long awaited fallout 4 in the horizon, I decided that it would be interesting to go back to the very first fallout, and look what made the fallout series so popular in the first place.

Now, i know that most of you started your fallout experience from fallout 3 or new vegas like i did. They were extremely fun post apocalyptic games. The enviroment, music, quests, creatures, retro futuristic feel, you get the point. But if you play the classic fallout, you will find the fun, awesome post apocalyptic feel just like in fallout 3 & new vegas.

The story in fallout 1 is quite simple, but still very interesting. Your vault's water purification chip has  broken, and the overseer of your vault sends you to find a new water chip from a nearby vault. Of course, things dont exactly go as planned, but i dont want to spoil the story much.

When you start a new game, you can customize your own character, or pick an arleady created one. After that, you start just outside your vault, ready to begin your adventure with a pistol that only has a handful of rounds, combat knife and couple of stimpaks. The atmosphere immediatley has the apocalyptic feel in it. The enviroment is open and quite detailed and the characters and quests you encounter are really memorable.

I absolutely loved the locations in fallout 1.  From the large trading city called The Hub where you can buy or sell supplies, to the city of Necropolis that is populated by ghouls. There are more very interesting locations in fallout 1 that you'll love to explore.

However the world of fallout 1 is not as open as in fallout 3. You can't just walk across the world map. You can only fast travel to locations on the world map. When stepping on the exit grid in any area, you will enter the world map. When you fast travel, there's a change you'll get random encounters, sometimes you'll just encounter normal folk passing by or enemies such as groups of super mutants and radscorpions that you have to fight. Speaking of combat...

The combat in fallout 1 is turn based. Fallout 1 uses an action point system where you have a limited amount of action points that you can spend to attack enemies, move around, switch weapons or look at your backpack. Once these points run out, The enemy gets the turn. Like in fallout 3, you can choose your primary combat style. There are 5 combat styles that are unarmed, melee weapons, guns, big guns and energy weapons. And i was actually surprised on how many guns there are in this game.  And there are alot.

Overall, fallout 1 is a fantastic game that i highly recommend fallout fans to play. 10/10

reviewText:
FalloutIf you're a fan of the series and you haven't played the original Fallout yet, I highly recommened it.

The gameplay and graphics are obviously very different from the more modern Fallout 3 and New Vegas, but the RPG and exploration elements are all there. Unlike those, the original Fallout is an isometric (not exactly, but whatever) and turn based RPG.
The main theme, concept and overall design are also shared with the other Fallout games.
You can still interact with every NPC, either by talking to them, bartering, stealing from them or just slaughtering them however you please. Watch out though, you'll easily die if you go up against enemies much better equipped than you or if you're significantly outnumbered.
You can also explore and interact with objects such as lockers, dresses, desks, etc... and search for various loot.
Most (if not all) of the chems like Stimpaks and Psychos are here too, along with weapons from pistols and rifles, to miniguns and energy weapons. The armor is slightly different, but you have Mad Max's leather jacket and Power Armor, so nothing to complain about there.
You have companions that will follow you around and help in combat, like good ol' Dogmeat.
The way you navigate around the map is a bit different though. The wasteland isn't just one huge map. If you want to travel to other cities/areas (there's 13 different locations, if I'm not mistaken) you leave the one you're at and a map comes up. From there, you choose where to go and all you do is watch a cute little map marker (you) move towards the destination, unless you encounter something (like raiders, mutants, a corpse to loot, etc..) or you deliberately stop.

The leveling system is pretty much the same, where you allocate SPECIAL points and choose 2 perks at the begining  of the game and gain experience to level up. You can then level up your skills (which I also think are the same from Fallout 3 & NV) and earn a perk every few levels.

One thing that's noticeably different however, is the way you make use of your skills. If you want to, for example, pick a lock, you'll have to go your Skilldex and select the skill you want to use (in this case, the Lockpick skill) and then you click on the object you want to use the skill on (the lock). Other skills also work like this, where you select the skill then the target to use the skill on. Except for Sneak, which you just click to start sneaking and that's it.

So yeah, to sum it up, if you're a Fallout fan you should definitely check this one out, even if just for the lore.
If you're new to the series, you're better off picking up 3 or NV first.

Side-note: This comes from a teenager who played Fallout 3 and New Vegas before this one, so there's no nostalgia involved here.

reviewText:
Released back in 1997, Fallout is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to Wasteland with heavy influences from the 1981 movie Mad Max, this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just ♥♥♥♥ someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll ♥♥♥♥, so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.

Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real ♥♥♥♥ happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.

The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time.

The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way, Fallout carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in Fallout: New Vegas. There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.

As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. First, there are major graphical bugs which can be fixed, but may persist nonetheless in more benign forms, which is to be expected of a game that's almost seventeen years old. Then there's some other annoying nitpicks, like unintuitive UI that feels clunky and the odd limitation like not being able to move more than 999 bottle caps at a time when bartering. The AI can be absolute garbage at times, too. Let's put it this way. There were times when I felt grateful that one of my followers was standing in a corner and not fighting, because that means he couldn't shoot me in the back. Without the ability to control your party, things can get pretty frustrating later in the game, when you're rolling with a huge posse to beat the final boss. Hint: save often, and in many slots.

So, would I reccomend this game? That depends. Are you looking for an old school CRPG with deep combat and meaningful choices and character growth? If so, then I'll be damned if you can find a better game than Fallout.

reviewText:
I bought this game after I played Fallout: New Vegas a while back, I never got around to playing it much, but from what I've played it's a very enjoyable game, the only flaw I'd say is that it's a tad dated for todays general audience, but if you're a Fallout fan, you need to try the game that started it all!

And also, if you're like me and got a couple colour related bugs when trying to play the game, the way in which to fix it is as follows:

1. Get FAllout FIXT from here: http://www.nma-fallout.com/showthread.php?194562

2. Copy that file over into your Fallout folder in Steam, so for example: Program Files (x86)/SteamApps/Common/Fallout

3. Run the patch (the file) and follow the instructions from it

4. You should have a file called ddraw.dll in your Fallout folder, rename this to f1ddraw.dll

5. You're now ready to start Fallout with Steam :3

reviewText:
I played this game to completion in 2001 when it was only available on cd-rom. Since then I purchased copies on GoG.com and Steam.

Fallout is the standard by which every other entry in the franchise should be judged. It is the more focused, balanced, thematically coherent Fallout experience available and the only one released with main designers Tim Cain, Leonard Boyarsky and Jason Anderson still on board.

By today's standards the game still hold up well even without fan patches and resolution mods, which are still strongly recommended. The engine and interface does show its age and the sequel, Fallout 2, improves a few things here and there. But the turn-based system and top down camera are not products of their times. First person view and real time combat are not modern". Changing the former for the latter doesn't constitute an improvement
date: but a complete change of direction.\n\nThis kind of game wasn't made that way due to technical limitations. Bethesda released its first Elder Scrolls game in 1994
recommended: the year Tim Cain started working on what would become Fallout. No

reviewText:
Released back in 1997, Fallout is still one of my favourite RPG's ever made. A spiritual successor to Wasteland with heavy influences from the 1981 movie Mad Max, this is a true blue, old school CRPG, no kiddies allowed. Don't expect any level of hand holding here. You're meant to explore, investigate, and actually think about what you do. Dialogue has meaning, and if you say or do the wrong thing, you might just ♥♥♥♥ someone off so bad you'll be screwed out of a quest forever. The combat is simple, yet deep enough to be engaging. Battles are turn-based, with action points determining how much you can do each turn. Most of the combat is driven by some heavy dice roll ♥♥♥♥, so expect to be screwed over by a bad critical hit and lose all of your health in a single turn, when previous attack dealt zero damage.

Most of the map is empty space. Instead of walking everywhere, you travel on a world map to locations of interest, wherein the real ♥♥♥♥ happens. Ranging from small settlements to the ruined remains of ancient cities, these locations are teeming with mysteries to unravel, choices to make, people to meet, items to loot, and a bunch of people to murder, if you're feeling sadistic. Quests often involve multiple outcomes, with several offering the choice between two opposing sides. Whether you're a ruthless mercenary willing to take on any job, a generous saviour, or an evil monster, this game accommodates you, allowing you to approach the game any way you see fit.

The game's SPECIAL system offers a surprising amount of depth in character creation. Will you be a gun-toting wanderer who solves problems with his guns, or a smooth-talking snake who solves problems without ever resorting to violence? How about a strongman who smashes his foes with a sledgehammer but is so stupid he can't even carry a conversation with people? Yes, you can do that. No matter which perks you pick or what skills you invest in, you're character will always end up with a different set of strengths and weaknesses. With these systems, the player is given a great deal of options that allow them to fine-tune their character, creating a vastly unique playthrough each time.

The story, characters, and setting are all iconic at this point. Though much of its aesthetic is derivative in some way, Fallout carved a unique personality of its own regardless. The narrative is nothing too complicated, and yet it's well-written and impactful at the same time, leading up to one of the best endings in RPG history. There's only three quests in the main plot lines, but these are long involving journeys that will take you all across post-apocalyptic Southern California. As you go from town to town, new quests, jobs, and side activities will open up, which can ultimately serve your primary objectives as well. Know that there is a finite end to the content, however. Though there's a lot to see and do (my first playthrough clocked in at about sixty hours), the game ends once you've beaten the main quest, and outside of that, you can't explore every nook and cranny like you can in Fallout: New Vegas. There's a limit to just how much you can do, but I feel this adds more to the experience, as it lends meaning to your actions. Don't expect to get every skill to a hundred and unlock every perk in a single playthrough.

As a game that came out in the late nineties, there are definitely some issues. First, there are major graphical bugs which can be fixed, but may persist nonetheless in more benign forms, which is to be expected of a game that's almost seventeen years old. Then there's some other annoying nitpicks, like unintuitive UI that feels clunky and the odd limitation like not being able to move more than 999 bottle caps at a time when bartering. The AI can be absolute garbage at times, too. Let's put it this way. There were times when I felt grateful that one of my followers was standing in a corner and not fighting, because that means he couldn't shoot me in the back. Without the ability to control your party, things can get pretty frustrating later in the game, when you're rolling with a huge posse to beat the final boss. Hint: save often, and in many slots.

So, would I reccomend this game? That depends. Are you looking for an old school CRPG with deep combat and meaningful choices and character growth? If so, then I'll be damned if you can find a better game than Fallout.

reviewText:
=--------REVIEW SYNOPSIS-------------=
Ah... the classic. It's ancient... very old. Despite that however, Bethesda still shows love to this timeless classic created by Fallout's original makers; Interplay. This is the one that started them all. It hasn't aged well as far as graphics and gameplay goes, but it's true to the RPG format, and one of the original US Turn-based RPGs from the 90s era. It spans the entireity of the Mojave Dersert-region... more precisely, the deserts of the California and Nevada regions. You begin as a Lone Wanderer set upon a quest to restore your Vault-Tek™ Vault's water chip; the sole thing that purifies the disease-ridden, irradiated waters of the surface world so that your vault's inhabitants will have fresh water to drink. It having broken down, you're sent out to find a new one. Along the way, you'll encounter many strange people... and many deadly enemies, not-so interesting companions... but companions none-the-less.

=--------PROGRESSIVE POINTS----------=
*Elder to the first US-based RPGs
*Turn-based (You are free to plan your next move, it could be your last!)
*Compatability/Optimized for Windows 7+ Operating Systems
*Compatability/Still contains the original version for 98/XP-based Operating Systems
*Brutal difficulty (Just how you remember it)

=--------CONTRARY POINTS-------------=
*Ancient graphical detail
*Linear storyline
*Limited range of weaponry/gear
*Brutal difficulty (No forgiveness for mistakes)
*Clunky UI (For what it was back in the day, hasn't aged well IMHO)

=--------PERSONAL GAME RESULTS-------=
I give this game a 8/10
I give this game a [LEGENDARY™ MOLE RAT STEW]

reviewText: Although I am not a fan of this kind of Isometric turn-based strategy games, I believe this game out classes both Fallout 3 and Fallout 4, but I do see it to be on-par with New Vegas. (As I am writing this review I have not completed Fallout 2's story yet.) I found the turn-based combat was a bit of a chore, so was inventory management, and even just wandering around certain areas. Still (IMHO) the story and immersion has aged much better than the actual mechanics of the game, and is the reason why I recommend it. The final cut-scene was also the saddest ending to a Fallout game. :(

reviewText:
Skip Fallout 3, avoid it like the plague and cancer it is to gaming as a whole. Get Fallout 1, Fallout 2, and Fallout: New Vegas.

This one is the most unforgiving of the three. You're on a time limit, certain dialogue options can completely destroy your reputation in some places, resulting in death or simply being unable to continue any further conversation.

The atmosphere is great, so is the story. The writing is exceptional, but nowhere nearly as good as Fallout 2 and Fallout: New Vegas. Keep in mind that while the series has always prided itself in player choices, the game kind of feels linear at the start. In fact, the dialogue is so inconsitent that it almost feels like Skyrim.

The combat system is also very comfy, just turn the combat speed up a bit so you don't have to sit there for 30 minutes and stare at some cave rat walk across the run while you're trying to run away from it.

reviewText: Fallout is a fantastic game back in the day, but it is becoming pretty obvious that it did not age very well, to put it simply the gameplay and design is outdated. If you never had a knack to play ancient pc role-playing games, chances are pretty good you will not like Fallout. The control scheme is god awful compared to modern standards, and the repetitive textures are just visually boring. The gameplay is very standard for rpg game of the 90s. While Fallout may lack all the basic mechanics that makes modern games great, its storyline, environment, and sound will remain eternal. Fallout created a precedent for all great RPG’s to follow, the ability to shape the ending of the game started here. Much like its sequels, Fallout’s entire game world is flipping massive. Overall this game is in desperate need of a remake.

reviewText:
I have already played this game via buying a soldout software collection. I spent many hours playing this game and I admit I needed a walkthrough as the difficulty of this game is based on you have a limited number of days, based on the storyline.

The Story: For those who don't know, you start out as a vault dweller whose parents took shelter in vault 13 along with many others to avoid the coming nucular missiles at the height of World War 3. The residents are meant to stay in the vault until such a time as the raditation levels have gone down low enough as to not be a issue, however your vault's water chip has broken. The main source of drinking water based on a recycling system in the vault. As they have no other option, they need to send out one of the residents and you volunteer to enter a world that has completely changed since your ancestors walked the surface during the war and find a new water chip as the Overseer knows of a nearby vault (Vault 15) which may have a spare chip to use.

The combat system is turn-based and on a invisible hex-grid. It is also based on Action Points and in combat uses what was called the VATS system where you can aim for a specific point on the creature, but if you were to take the trait that lets you shoot more often (forgot it's name) you will be unable to do accurate aiming. It's a old-school PC RPG where your decisions are totally up to you and ethics are optional in how you get the waterchip or where from. With multiple endings and detailed tellings of what happened to the places you visited, after you left leaves the game open for many multiple play throughts  for endless gameplay and always discover new things and easter eggs such as the holy hand grenade." and other references too numerous to count.

A brilliant game and well worth a purchas if you are after a old-school RPG
date: but as it is so old and not altered for modern systems (unlike on GoG) you will need to look up how to run the game without weird graphical glitches."

reviewText:
+ amazingly interesting quests
+ great RPG system, perks
+ unforgettable soundtrack
+ dark, yet humorous
+ funny and believable dialogues
+ incredible atmosphere
+ challenging to beat; not overly hard though
+ runs perfecty on modern systems after one fan-made patch
- doesn't run perfectly on modern systems without the fan-made patch

The ultimate post-nuclear experience. Forget the F3/NV; Fallout 1 (and Fallout 2) is how the post-apocalyptic world could actually look like.

Harshness, seriousness and darkness of the post-apocalyptic world? It's in it.
Humour, hyperbole, light tone and pop-culture references? It's in there, without diminishing the serious tone of the game.

INCREDIBLE dialogues and your possibilities in it. Great music, fits the atmosphere perfectly. Decent storyline. The number of possibilities on how you could play through this game is uncountable. You can beat this game in 9 minutes 17 seconds (literally, speedrun is on youtube somewhere) or in average 20 hours without getting bored for 1 second. For me it's possibly the best RPG out there.

New Fallouts were decent games but sh*t-tier Fallouts. You want to know why is Fallout considered one of the best RPG series ever? Play this (or Fallout 2) and forget the sequels for now.

↑ all of this applies to Fallout 2 as well

reviewText:
For all its weeping sores, the best PC game of the 1990s except for Homeworld, and probably the best RPG on Steam. Lots of freedom, likeable characters, an intriguing backstory, a main quest you can straight-up fail, some of the greatest endings in any game, and a gorgeous dark-ambient soundtrack.

On the down side, the interface is clunky and slow, especially inventory. NPC sidekicks can be frustrating to work with and will often harm you or each other. (It's not nearly as bad as some clumsy players will tell you it is.) And a few quests can hinge on pixel hunting - not intentionally, but simply because items can be hard to spot against the dithery backgrounds.

Be advised that all combat in this game is turn-based. It's fun, but it's NOT optional like you see in Fallout 3 and New Vegas. You will take turns spending action points on a hex grid, every fight. Fallout is a slow RPG. It is not by any definition an action game.

Highest possible recommendation.

reviewText:
It's Worth It, Just Be Prepared to Mod It

Fallout's strengths lie in two areas: atmosphere and customization. The atmosphere of Fallout is amazing. It's one of the few games I feel that has gotten its atmosphere down right, combining a dangerous and barren post-apocalyptia with a retro 1950s undertone, and maintains a great balance between feeling ridiculous and serious. The story isn't anything to write home about, but it's an effective motivating force for the game. With that in mind, know that if you pick up Fallout, do NOT consult any walkthrough or wiki when playing it because, trust me, it'll spoil the fun. Fallout is the type of RPG that's made a whole lot better when you live with your consequences and aren't certain about where the story will take you.

As for the customization, Fallout has it in plentiful supply and I'm not just refering to the moral choices available to you. Rather, it's the character customization which is some of the best. Between getting to specialize in a wide variety of weapon types to being able to having your intelligence level effect your choices in the game (Anything below an Intelligence of 4 makes you a bumbling idiot, and this is reflected in game by your dialogue options which are limited to me have trouble thinking") there's a great amount of replayability to this game.

However
date: while I recommend Fallout it does come with a bundle of bugs
recommended: some of which have the potential to be game breaking such as being trapped in a corner by an unmovable companion NPC. Because of this
hoursPlayed: I recommend you mod it. My personal recommendation is called "Fallout FIXT" by Sduibek. It's a great megamod which fixes a lot of problems
voteText: and is VERY customizable allowing you to choose between general bug fixes and improvements
helpfulPercent: or changing the feel of the game entirely. It's a great download.\n\nAnyway

reviewText: Fallout 1 is a very ♥♥♥♥ing good game. In fact, it's probably one of the best games of all time, and is definitely the best RPG ever made. Everything from the combat, which still holds up well today, to the dialogue, which is incredibly deep and satisfying with many options and even more outcomes, even to the ambient music, is perfect. Though the main allure here is the role-playing. Your stats actually matter (unlike the most recent FO games to an extent). In fact, early game your stats are the only thing that will keep you alive. If you chose wrong or without thinking, you're ♥♥♥♥ed. There are so many different outcomes to every quest and the game is very narrative-driven, but it still manages that feeling of complete player freedom that Bethesda have sacrificed so much to achieve in the newer games. Really, it's just ♥♥♥♥ing awesome. Go buy it.

reviewText:
Personal rating: 10/10
Replayability: High
Budget: Worth it if you're a fan only as the game is very old and dated. If you have no knowledge of the game, don't bother throwing a cent at it.
Lenght: Unknown. At least a week. Probably more.

Fallout is an old classic. If you've played fallout 3 or New Vegas and taken an interest in the series and want to try this, I seriously recommend watching a few youtube vids first, as the game is very old. It's not exactly easy to adjust to a game this dated.

That said, even on windows 7, it plays without error.

The game will probably remind a lot of people, initially of the more recent fallout games. They seem do have done a great job of passing on the setting. Bear in mind that this is turn-based combat, and top-down view and isometric. It's truly an oldie.

The game is crafted with a lot of detail in mind. Each map allows for every single item to be examined, and unlike in more recent RPG's in general, you will not be told when to use skills. There is no tutorial (to my knowledge) but the game isn't super hard to figure out, and if it becomes tricky there are guides on the internet.

It's a good holiday project, but hardly a treat for a gamer who seeks a visual challenge and revolutionary gameplay. For gamers interested in gaming history or people in general who can stand playing old games, you will have a chance to experience a rolepalying game that dates to the time when people really knew how to craft a world with eye for detail.

Personally I tried fallout when I was a child, having barely a clue what I was doing. I've since stumbled on it again and again with friends who time and time again referred to it as a classic. It truly is.

Good game. If you're like me and you played Fallout 3 and New Vegas before this it might be a bit hard to get used to the old style of things, but you'll find it to be quickly addictive. Heavily reccomend looking at some mods to remedy ♥♥♥♥ like this. Still a gud game though

reviewText:
Fallout is a controversial came to me because there are many good and bad things about it. It can be genuinely fun, but you have to be willing to overlook a few problems.

For one, non-violent character builds (i.e. focus on skills like sneak, speech, science, etc) are pretty much impossible to play for several reasons. A) There are random encounters in this game, which you will get constantly while fast traeveling. Unless you're really, really, lucky, you will get murdered by raiders and scorpions over and over again. B) You will miss out on XP through combat, which will make you way too low level.

Secondly, most skills in this game are uneccessary or plainly useless.

In order to have fun, I recomend you play the following character. Choose gifted and fast shot as traits, lockpick, science, and small guns as tag skills. Then go with 2 cha, 4 int, 4 str, 10 end, 10 agility, 10 per, and 5 luck. Trust me, just do it.

It kind of feels like a let down in that you don't get a lot of freedom to do what you want. This game is very combat-oriented.

Another problem is the graphics. It personally didn't bother me, but I know it can upset some people. If that's important to you, maybe don't play it.

Lastly, the game is arbitrarily hard. The first time I saw a mutant, I got blasted to bits in one hit. Make  sure to save often and I recomend playing on easy, because Fallout enemies are super unfair.

However, don't let that stop you from enjoying it. There are many good things about it also.

What I really enjoyed was the simple fact that no other franchise really makes post-apocalytpic RPGs. The enemies look all mad max style, how cool is that? The setting is really cool, and frankly, underused. I've always maintained that interesting settings *make* RPGs.

The story of Fallout is actually pretty interesting, even if it is rather bare-bones.

I was also really impressed by the goal of Fallout: you have only 150 days to get a water chip, which your vault needs. You're on your own and you have to figure out where it is quickly. It's almost like a sleuth or detective RPG.

If you feel like the good outwieghs the bad, you should try it. It's not a perfect game and I probably wouldn't finish it gain, but it's a unique experience.

reviewText:
Things I Liked:
Good Story
Very Strategy-Centric - hexagonal tiles mean that strategy is key
Variety in weapons
Lore is really interesting

Things I Didn't:
More RTS-like than RPG, although RPG elements are there
The graphics do not work on modern machines - many graphical glitches on my machine
Combat is action point reliant - can be pretty dull
Game mechanics are not very well explained - trial and error
Once you die, you lose your character (may be a welcome challenge for some, but I am not a fan)
No autosaves (adds to annoyance of above point)

The Fallout series is well known by the gaming community, mainly for Fallout 3 and New Vegas but many have missed the first entry in the series, which can be picked up pretty cheaply on Steam.

I had pretty low expectations for this game, being released in 1997 and all, but even so I was honestly disappointed from the get go, when I couldn't boot up the game, and when I did the opening cutscene wouldn't show without rainbows fizzing across my screen.

Anyway, as I got into the game these glitches went away for the most part, and I could get onto playing the game, which was difficult without any clues on where to go or how quickly (you are given a time limit to complete the game, by the way). The storyline you follow is dull, although the background information is really interesting, with the end-of-the-world scenario that kicked it all off in pretty much every game since. be prepared though, this information is pretty much shoved in your face every time you talk to anyone. They respond to a two word question with a five hundered word essay, and you have to read it all to make sense of what's going on.

The combat is what I thought the Fallout series would excel at, but I was wrong. enemies surround you far too quickly, you have to use 'action points' like a turn based strategy, in fact that's what the combat is, and I find it a hard concept to master.

Overall this game is great for its story and lore but not so strong with its combat and mechanics in the modern era. Recommended if you can put up with the flaws of older titles.

reviewText:
Having been a veteran of Fallout near 13 years now, I recall my first time playing the first Fallout. Back then I was pretty young and didn't have exactly a firm grasp of reality and the seriousness of Fallout.

Now, upon purchasing the classic pack, I delved back into the world of Fallout, and after having some memories flood back and some trials and errors, I once again (without help this time) beat Fallout, I survived, I learned, I made decisions that made me question my humanity as a whole, thank god for the comic relief in game otherwise I would've gotten depressed real fast! Now that the compliments are outta the way, let me begin by saying this a game befitting anyone's game library.

Fallout, as a whole, makes you question and discover yourself (Get ready for group therapy session!), its amazing locales and set-up make it a unique game to play, I could actually spend hours trying to figure out what and where I find the Red Ryder LE BB Gun (Special Encounter). Beautifully detailed yet desolate and unforgiving landscapes and settlements make for a great experience, mechanics are smooth and simple, once you figure them out of course.
I was pretty much thrown into the game without prior knowledge of the controls or how combat and interaction function, once I remembered some bits and pieces and tried different things, it was simple.

A colorful cast of characters that antagonizes and emphasises on a great deal of comical and serious matters, each one, be it a talking head" or just a regular NPC
date: will have you wonder "Do I join this group? Do I shoot this guy? Why does the man keep screaming about cheese? Should I prevent or stay out of this fight that possibly decides the outcome of an entire game?"\n\nLadies and gentlemen
recommended: I tried my best to explain what Fallout entails
voteText: how it makes me feel
helpfulPercent: and how much I love it. But I sadly cannot put into full detail how amazing Fallout is.\n\nAll I can say is Fallout is like a wonderful sight of a game
votesHelpful: a whole lot of what-ifs
votesTotal: and lovely interaction.\n\nThough humanity may have blown itself up
votesFunny: that is not the end of the story
commentsCount: because war... War never changes...\n\n10/10."

reviewText: 9/10 would barter for again. It's kind of a shame they never made any sequels to this game, but maybe that's for the best. I'm sure that if Fallout became an ongoing series, then by now, it'd be in the hands of a AAA publisher who'd be busy gutting the series one game at a time by replacing the story and dialogue with half-realized trendy gameplay elements, retconning the original game fifty times with every new installment, and leeching off unpaid work by the modding community while simultaneously relying on them to make the games playable to begin with. Yeah, I suppose it could be a lot worse. I can live with the fact that they only ever made one Fallout.

reviewText: This game is the beginning of my favourite series of games ever. I assumed that due to it's age and the companies behind it, that it would be pretty bad and boring, but I was very wrong. This game is full of a fair amount of quests that all have good story to them. The visuals are fine when the HD patch is applied. There is lack of audio in the game aside from the odd sound effect and combat related sounds such as gunshot. The game also has fairly slow paced gameplay and you'd have to be patient to deal with it at times. The game has turn-based combat using a targeting system called V.A.T.S." that works on percentages. The games RPG elements are detailed with many perks and skills to train as well as using speech options that effect how the game plays out.\nIf you're a fan of post-apocalyptic setting
date:
don't mind the dated graphics and slow paced gameplay. This game is for you.

12/15 - "Brilliant beginning to a brilliant series"
"

reviewText: The controls aren't initially too bad, especially when you finally master them. Unfortunately, Black Isle Studios didn't have the knack to implement an abundance of voice actors. Truth be told there are only a handful of them in the entire game. Everything else is good old fashion dialogue. Sure, you might here me and other people complain about this. But let's just say, for the shake of this review. I get over the fact the game only has a limited amount of voice actors until Fallout 3. The only major problem I've encountered thus far with Fallout 1 through 2 (including Fallout Tactics) is the despicable combat system. I mean this combat system sucks.. I'm talking atari style combat.. A friendly individual fires first, then a hostile target fires second. It essentially goes back and fourth until one or the other is dead. This is extremely unrealistic, and truthfully. I don't believe there was any excuse for this whatsoever. Take my word for it, I'm a huge fan of the Fallout series; but this is just ridiculous. In closing this message, I want to add the story is of course outstanding. I hope one day they'll consider doing a remastered version of both Fallout 1 and Fallout 2. Preferably with Fallout 4's new creation engine.

I picked it up simply for storyline and slight nostalgia.  Which is what I think most players picked it up for.  To complete the set and get that little bit of Lore you always wondered about.

Seriously, buy this game only if you want to experience the classics.  It's like buying Final Fantasy 1 cause you enjoyed 10 so much that you want to know the first game better.  It's a completely different beast but worth experiencing even if you never finish it. Or like playing Pac Man or Pong.  It's a classic worth trying.

reviewText:
This is not like Fallout 3 or New Vegas. This game is tough especially for people who are not experienced in cRPGS. With that being said, this game is enjoyable- i clocked in about 25 hours.

This game has many problems - bugs, broken and cut quests, outdated graphics(even with highrez mod), not fully fledged or connecting dialogue, outdated gameplay mechanics, having to optimize this game for your comp by yourself(THANKS STEAM...) and my main gripe that this game feels to me a beta for fallout 2 which most people say is the superior between the two.

I feel this game gets the classic nod, because of what it brings to the western rpg genre  - a unique rpg system with perks, special stats and skills which affect the world around you, ambigous morality, interesting setting and lore, great story line, fairly good dialogue, random encounters.

AS a person who's first fallout game was New Vegas, i felt really out of place when i first dl this game. Its really difference and theirs a learning curve to it.

This game is old and outdated - this is true no argument about that. So it will affect my final score.

My Score system: 10/10 is a perect, 5/10 is average, and 0/10 Horrible.

This game is a 7/10, a good game. It should be played if your a fallout fan and have never touched this old cRPG classic.

reviewText:
This game came out in 1997 and it surprisingly holds up to this day. I was afraid I wouldn't like it because of how old it was and that I had played Fallout 3 and New Vegas first but I was completely wrong. It's basically the same as Fallout 3 and NV but isometric.

The classic Fallout charm is present in this game with a main story and a few side quests. Though the game seems kinda basic in some areas a lot of the game seems a lot deeper and more indepth than a lot of Modern RPG's. At the time I can imagine this was quite revolutionary setting the standard for RPG's in general.

Only once or twice I got fustrated at the game, not due to the lack of direction but due to the logic I was using to solve a problem not working even though I felt like it should. However it turned out the thing I was doing you were actually meant to do later on but I originally didn't try it again until I looked up I was doing it correctly just in the wrong area. Oh well.

As I mentioned earlier, the lack of direction is a big thing in this game. The first quest is Find the water chip. Here is a place it MIGHT be." and that's it. It's very satisfying to complete quests because of this as you need to ask around and gather information to solve the quests for yourself.

My only complaint with the game is that the combat is unforgiving and can be fustrating at times as you can get instakilled just because of a random critical hit. The accuracy is also unforgiving at times as well especially in skills that you haven' trained as much. It's not that it's stupid it's far too unforgiving for what it is.

The bottom line:
If you enjoyed the other Fallout games (including 3 and NV) you will like this one."

reviewText: I missed this in 1997.  While the story telling might have been top at the time, judging by the 9/10 scores it got back in the day, the quest system is just abysmal. reviewText: Well, at least I can tell myself that I tried. After hearing around the whole internet that this game was definetly better than Fallout 3 and on, I decided to buy it. I was sure that the game would have some pretty bad graphics and what not, but personally I don't mind old games and bad graphix at all. What a game should have, its value. A game with a good story, a good gameplay. and a good fluidity , it's a good game. Fallout 1 only gets the story characteristic right. Yes, the story is amaing, and t gets the feeling and atmosphere right. It was amazing to get inmersed into the wasteland for the first time, but, that's about it. Honestly, even modern Fallouts get this right. The problem with this game is the gameplay, and the pacing. My god.\nThe gameplay is horrible. It is so slow, and ridiclous, that it makes it boring. It's basicaly a point and click battle system, with enemies that deal ridiculous damage and never miss, while you are too weak and are constantly missing.   It never made me feel good, like an RPG usually does, about getting stronger with EXP., and then tackling the stronger enemies and achieving victories. Why? cause, and this is the best part, at the beginning of the game, you have a stupid time limit. You can't go around exploring the wasteland and getting stronger at your own pace! Nope. You need to hurry and finish part of the main quest with as little moves as possible, so you don't get a game over. If you are like me and you don't like looking up things at google to solve games, then you'll probably have to start over from scratch more than once to figure out what to do to solve this problem. It's just not fun. Anybody that likes this game is because they feel nostalgia. That's it. The game itsef is garbage, quite honestly. Every single character is shallow, except for the final boss, and the side-quest are crap. If you lived in the 80's and 90's this game would've been mind blowing. Today, it's crap.

reviewText: Don't bother purchasing Fallout, if you're interested in the older installments purchase Fallout 2.\n\nThe game is riddled with bugs, so don't bother playing it without the Fallout FIXD Mod.  The actual game itself leaves a lot to be desired, as the gameplay and story are paper thin.  Most perks and skills are useless in the game, so you'll likely need to read up on how to build your character before you begin playing, so as to not put yourself at a major disadvantage at the onset.  This is extremely dissapointing for an RPG game, as it forces you to play in a certain way, not the way you want to play.  The world is small, and main baddies (super mutants), play almost no role in the game, save one instance, until the finale.  The controls take a few hours to get used to, but even after a day of playing, you may still be unsure how to approach certain quests and objectives presented within the game.  (You need to use" a radio to disable the forcefields at the military base
recommended: and good luck figuring that out without using google.)\n\nThere's little reason to explore quests on the side
hoursPlayed: some are only initiated with very specific dialouge (despite it seeming as though you've reached an agreement)
voteText: and some quests are hinted at but don't even exist at all!  The rewards that come from completing the various quests are useless unless there's some type of loot you'll find along the way.  Don't bother saving up money to purchase the various in game weapons
helpfulPercent: as you'll find all the ammo and weaponry you need along the way.  There are only a few talking heads in the game
votesHelpful: but other than the Mutant at the military base and the "Master" during the end-game
votesTotal: the characters are bland
votesFunny: boring
commentsCount: and offer little in the way of interesting information or background.  All of this takes away from the games interesting premise that paved the way for much better Fallout sequels.   Towards the end of the game
column16: I finally realized that there's little meaningful dialogue and reason to explore the map and grinded through it
column17: only to have the game crash at the end.\n\nGood aspects of the game include the excellent voice acting (despite most of it being shallow)
column18: and a few interesting story bits provided by the two meaningful characters.  The combat can also be fun in final stages of the game
column19: but boring at the beggining and middle portions.  Overall the atmosphere and originality of the game and its sequels makes the games existence seem worthwhile.  However
column20: as a standalone game it has little redeeming qualities

column22: you're better off watching the cutscenes on Youtube and passing on this so call "classic"."

reviewText:
I never thought that a classic game such as this would be so bad.

I really wanted to play this for the story but man this just isn't worth it. If you genuinely think this is a 10/10 game you must have been 10 years old when you last played this. Nostalgia has to be the only cure for this.

As I'm writing this I just finally ragequit after playing an 9 hour session, in the middle of which I had to start a new character because I found out that I had basically just lost the game there and there was no way to return. The reason I just ragequit is that pretty much the same thing happened again. I went into an area from which I could not get out alive. Of course I only had one save because I couldn't ever have expected ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t like this.

The game forces you to save every 5 seconds because you never know when YOU are going to ♥♥♥♥ YOURSELF over by choosing one of the wrong answers in some conversation (even though it might be a completely normal thing to say).
If you fail to choose the right" thing to say from the 4 or 5 dialogue options some NPCs will NEVER TALK TO YOU AGAIN. Their hatred for you burns with the heat of the sun because you asked how they were doing instead of if they had a job for you.

The NPCs also seem to ignore the stats that bind the player. They shoot you with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ starting pistols from a mile away and do damage you can only dream of doing yourself.
Other than that the combat mechanics are pretty interesting and work well. You can plan your moves well and do some really nice tacticool stuff. It was really satisfying to clear out the Raider Camp but after meeting Super Mutants and finding out that they have infinite health I just didn't know what the hell I was supposed to do to get more levels.

Some of the objectives were also almost impossible to find out for yourself. Sometimes there is a pixel-fine line between advancing to the next area and "nothing interesting happens". I only checked a guide once to see what to do next and I am sure I would have been there for two hours and restarted the whole game after that if I didn't do it.

Maybe it was all my fault and I'm really bad at video games. But damn this game isn't hard
date:
it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. Mechanical difficulty is entirely different from what this game is.

Don't buy this game if you want to find out about the Fallout story. Just go read it.

"

reviewText:
Ah, the original Fallout. One of the classic RPGs that's generally (and unfortunately) overlooked by people today.

This game would be slightly better if the port was updated to the point where it wasn't so glitchy. First of all, the cutscenes are very blurry and rainbow-y. Second, there is no sort of instruction at all (which isn't Steam's fault, the only instructions that came with this game originally came in the manual booklet). Thirdly, there's few to no options with which to change resolution or full-screen/window.

The game itself is much more difficult than I expected, which is neither a plus nor a minus. Some games are harder than others, so what?

Honestly, while I like the game, I don't really recommend buying it unless you're willing to fix the bugs and learn to play completely by yourself.

reviewText:
I had high hopes in this legendary game, and was terribly disappointed.
From the beginning, the game plays extremely slow and felt more like work than like fun. I seriously had to force myself to keep playing the game, and if i hadnt paid for it, i would have already deinstalled it!
About the reasons: The difficulty is extremely hard, as the hero is very weak, and hardly able to kill anything at the beginning. Be prepared to reload very often, as random encounters are usually much more than you could take, and as the leveling process is painfully slow!
Then, as you would expect from such an old game, the graphic is terrible, and the game mechanics are outdated. Dont expect the comfort, complexity and polish of modern games. Without fanmods, this game is hardly playable at all, and even with, the game crashes constantly and lots of bugs remain.
And finally, there is a time-limit for your mission, which causes a tough game to become stressy and annoying.

Personally, i cannot recommend this game at all!
