reviewText:
Disclaimer: I have previously played Fallout 3 and enjoyed both the game and universe. That being said, I looked into the original games a bit before purchasing to see what type of gameplay it was.

The Basics:  This game has a top-down view with turn-based combat. The game came out in 1997, so the graphics are starting to show their age.

My Opinion: I didn't care for this game at all. There are two big things that ruined the game for me: poor direction and terrible combat.
When it comes to quests, I would like some for of, the main mission/quest is in this general direction." I want some idea of knowing how I can progress. I am not asking for the game to hold my hand. I actually don't care for games that hold my hand. However
date: I shouldn't have to look at a walkthrough to tell me where I have to go for the main story. It would be one thing if I didn't know where to find a side mission/quest. Sometimes people get lost in games
recommended: sure. You start out lost at the beginning of the game with no sense of direction in a cave.\nThe combat was the second issue I had. It's clunky and bland. Maybe I just didn't play far enough into the game
hoursPlayed: but it just felt sloppy and wasn't engaging. It didn't feel like I was able to do anything. You start off with all of your items
voteText: and weapons
helpfulPercent: in your bag. You have nothing equpped. Take a few steps forward and you are in your first battle. Now
votesHelpful: almost every single game I have ever played has you start with a weapon equipped
votesTotal: or you fight to gain that first weapon. As I said
votesFunny: you have your first weapon
commentsCount: why the hell is it not equipped or tell you to check inventory? So after you either fail or realize
column16: "oh hey
column17: I have a ♥♥♥♥ing gun that nobody told me about
column18:
you finally equip it. Now you can fight rats and point blank range with a gun. You shoot, you miss. You shoot again, you miss again. Meanwhile, this rat is going to beat the hell out of you and you lose half of your health while shooting and outline of the rat around him.

Conclusion: This game isn't for me. The sloppy direction and combat are what drove me away. Maybe the game is too dated. Maybe if I had tried it a few years soon, I might have been able to enjoy it. The fact is that now I don't find the game enjoyable at all.

3/10

reviewText:
Never having played this game back in it's heyday and after hearing how asweomse this game is from every corner of the internets. (Thank you Al Gore!) I decided to pick it up on sale and give it a go. I was surprised that I just couldn't get into it. It's not the graphics, I love old school games. It's not the character building. I loved that. My dissapointment set in for the first time when I traveled on the overworld map. You just click where you want to go and a red dot moves across the map to the position you chose. That's it.

Example:  https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5lgMrJpnnhM#t=14m50s Skip to 14 minutes 45s to see what Im talking about.

I guess I was just expecting more after all the hype. Maybe Wasteland 2 will satisfy the oldschool post apocalyptic itch for a whole new generation. Myself included.

reviewText:
Fallout will please roleplaying fans everywhere. Set in a post apocalyptic world, Fallout starts out with you (the hero) leaving the safety of your underground village to search for a water purifier which is essential for the continued survival of your village.
The outer world has a similar feeling to the 'MAD MAX' movies without the cars. Through many towns you interact with seperate factions and gangs, often invoving your self in quests, or trying to avoid being killed!
You can design your own character or use a predesigned character. You have several statistics which combined with some 'characteristics' give you a list of percentile abilities (e.g. small gun 65% - meaning you have a 65% chance of hitting an enemy in normal conditions!).
The world is set out in several sections. Based on a vast grid, you have many wilderness boxes and several 'towns' such as Junktown etc. In the wilderness you can encounter travelling tradesmen or evil creatures out to get you.
The game is very intuitive allowing you to do most things with your mouse. The combat is particularly easy, aiming at an opponent gives you a pecentage chance of hitting. You can either shoot or try a different opponent. You often meet peole who will join your group, but be careful not to stand in front of them as they often manage to accidently hit you in combat!
The graphics and sound are very atmospheric adding a little excitement to the game. Although the plot is weak, I found the game to be very enjoyable with some neat touches here and there. This game is definately a must for most rpgers out there.

reviewText: Fallout, the first game in one of my favorite series of all time.  This game is awesome.  The pacing is great and isn't as difficult as the second one.  It works super well on any pc which is awesome.  The game's combat and exploration are its trademarks.  You can loot, kill, and do just about anything.  It is alot more forgiving than Fallout 2 but it isn't as long.  The story itself is unique and well paced.  I never felt while I was playing the game was taking too long.  I liked how you can find all the cool easter eggs that most companies don't ever put in their games now.  Get this game and it is on sale plenty of times so get it during one of the many sales steam does.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I was first intorduced to the Fallout series when I played Fallout 3, which my friend highly recommended. He had been trying for weeks to get me to play, I finally gave in a decided to try it and I LOVED IT! I went on a Fallout binge, often playing for 10 or more hours per day. Then I finished the game and moved on to New Vegas.
Recently I decided I wanted to go back to the beginning and play the earlier games. I wasn't expecting very much, especially since it was made in 1997; but when I first started it I felt like it was a waste of money(even though I bought the bundle while it was on sale). After getting my butt kicked by Radscorpions and not knowing how to get better equipment I was about to give up, then I started goofing around and found out what I wanted to know.
So far I haven't progressed ver far in the main questline, but I have developed a new found respect for the original, in my opinion being better than the newer ones. The areas are quite large, the music is addicting,and the combat system is not as bad I though it to be.
My biggest challenge when I started playing was adjusting to the combat system. Since I started Fallout playing Fallout 3 it took some time to get used to the combat system in this game. After I got past that I started to love this game.
I highly recommend this game to any fan of Fallout

reviewText: If you want to see where it all started, check out the first installment of one of the best game sagas in existence.\nFallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game features a pretty great story line, creative and compelling and before its time. Character customization even in this early installment still gives you a lot of control over your character and their capabilities, and plot lines altered by players' decision give the player a sense of ownership over the outcomes. Games like this spark the fire that become today's RPG gaming. Turn-based game play involves a little more forethought in strategy than fans of modern games are used to, you find less quick reaction is useful and more preparation and anticipation of combat needs will save you. It is important to remember that 1997 is before the time of auto-save.

reviewText: Let me start this review off by saying DAMN, this game kicks ♥♥♥. Now that thats out of the way lets discuss why it kicks ♥♥♥. First off graphics; the graphics aren't great after all the game did come out almost 2 decades ago but even so they still hold up fairly well. The gameplay is good but has its fair share of bugs. Do NOT go into this game thinking you will automatically kick but, YOU WON'T. You will die many, many times before your'e even adequetly prepared for regular enemies. things got SO bad for me that i had to completely start over from scratch and that is NOT a fun thing to have to do. The story is good for its time and the characters are well written though the voices are wonky. great game overall and i highly recommend you purchase it IF it is on sale. NOT worth dropping 10 dollars for an almost 20 year old game. 9/10

reviewText:
My Fallout experiences and what I thought of Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game

My introduction to the Fallout franchise was through a friend of my elder brothers. Before going out, he peered his head into my room and left an Xbox 360 copy of Fallout 3 on my table for me to borrow. I was addicted. The start of the summer of 09' was spent wondering the DC ruins and soaking up everything that that insane game had to offer.

A year later in 2010, New Vegas had came out. I ravenously guzzled it down within a month and was still hungry for more. For a massive history-buff like me, and all though it's set in the 2100's, the Fallout series offered a unique experience and had me totally engrossed in it's seemingly endless codex-like information and lore.

So, some time later it is payday December 2013. By now I am on Steam (albeit still a noob) and I am searching the store. I get home from a freezing night of Christmas shopping with the girlfriend, and I notice the 'Fallout Bundle' going for around £3. Was this real?

As soon as Fallout 1 had Installed I jumped on in.

It took a while to get used to the old turn taking system, but you have to be open minded. Playing game series backwards in age is going to be off putting so you have to try and enjoy it for what it is. Saying this though, I got bored (Guilty as charged) and didn't play it for about half a year. As much as it pains me to say this, I just lost my will to play it entirely from sheer boredom.

Into the not-so-distant future and the Fallout crave had started to come back. I reinstalled F:aPNRPG and jumped on into a new game. This time round, I curbed my ego and instead of playing Fallout 1 like I played Fallout 3 and NV, I decided to take a completely different approach.

I forced myself to remember, this game was made when I was fifteen months old. Times were different back then. So I dumped myself in the desk chair, grabbed a tall drink of cola and walked out into the Vault 13 Caves.

I didn't look back, and what a game it was. A solid 10/10. A beautifully minimalist/simple and believable plot too. Try it for yourself.

If you are approaching this game from the future like I did, then be open minded. Only play it when you crave to. Otherwise you'll get bored and this gem will be missed out on.

Next up, Fallout 2.

reviewText:
I was first intorduced to the Fallout series when I played Fallout 3, which my friend highly recommended. He had been trying for weeks to get me to play, I finally gave in a decided to try it and I LOVED IT! I went on a Fallout binge, often playing for 10 or more hours per day. Then I finished the game and moved on to New Vegas.
Recently I decided I wanted to go back to the beginning and play the earlier games. I wasn't expecting very much, especially since it was made in 1997; but when I first started it I felt like it was a waste of money(even though I bought the bundle while it was on sale). After getting my butt kicked by Radscorpions and not knowing how to get better equipment I was about to give up, then I started goofing around and found out what I wanted to know.
So far I haven't progressed ver far in the main questline, but I have developed a new found respect for the original, in my opinion being better than the newer ones. The areas are quite large, the music is addicting,and the combat system is not as bad I though it to be.
My biggest challenge when I started playing was adjusting to the combat system. Since I started Fallout playing Fallout 3 it took some time to get used to the combat system in this game. After I got past that I started to love this game.
I highly recommend this game to any fan of Fallout

reviewText:
War... War never changes.
A concept that has driven a younger self to delve into the depths of human history and indulge in the ages of humanities stife.
Fallout and its proceeding series has taken a Post- Nuclear apocalyptic outcome of humanity, peeking subsequently in the attitude, culture and design of 1950's United States of America...  on October 23, 2077 a final Nuclear showdown between the powerhouses of the world finally push the resource crippled Earth to its limits.
The aftermath that ensued is what caries the Fallout series...

2161... 84 years after the grand conclusion to Man's pinacle.

Unfotunately, the scarred earth was not left without it's demons looming. Pulling humanity ever downward or to one binding will or another.

This did not mean all was lost though... Emergent groups; once sealed away long ago before the world went silent still had a chance to re-inherit a land all but forsaken by it's previous masters.

The time had come for the those fortunate enough to hide away in sealed underground fortresses known as Vaults. These Vault Dwellers experienced a different form of life... Far from the raptured barren lands of the nuclear wasteland that was now the Americas.

Fallout will take you through the Western United States of America, your mission... Save the Vault, your objectives, retrieve a Water-purification chip  and return with any details of the land.

With the goal established you are pushed onto a desert frontier, far from the lush lands that once beheld the view.

The game plays from a Top-down view of your characters, combat revolves around Action Points and maybe a bit of luck ;) to resolve any experience. Weapons range from rocks, spears and knives... To sub-machine guns, rifles and shotguns... Chainguns and rockets all the way up to the sci-fi laser and plasma weaponry in similar previous fashions.

The Vault Dwellers or later to be known to most as The Wanderer... journey is one that always kept smirk of satisfaction on my face. The stories created here are later on exemplified in later games from the series.

TL;DR: A game that was likely overlooked if you're in your early 20's and younger. Take the time, see how the story began and enjoy some good old fashion hexa-based combat.

reviewText:
I could not tell you about my love for  the first fallout game, but I shall try. Fallout is the story of the vault dweller......no duh. He is sent out to look for a water chip because the one in his vault has died. It is a race against time to save your vault and meet some rather odd people along the way.

The atmosphere for this game is great. It is rather dark and sometimes rather depressing, however, it has some of the best dark humor I have seen in a game to date. The only problem I have with this game is that it is slightly unforgiving and will take a while to understand what you need to do and where you need to go. There is also a time limit at the start of the game, but it goes away after you main goal is done (Well, it gives you 13 in game years, which is more then enough time to finish all the side quest and more).

I give Fallout a nice 4/5  for being a great game that holds up rather well for today's standards.

reviewText:
It has taken me 15 years to complete Fallout 1. Some people say it's the best RPG of ALL TIME! I have found out the truth behind this claim.

It's a third person isometric game from 1997. It ran fine on my widescreen Windows 7 set up. Note you need to running a patched version where some bugs are taken out. I played the Steam version that ran fine.

The game is set in the USA in a post nuclear war era where much of civilisation has broken down or turned to dust. Some people have survived the nuclear fallout out by living in specialist underground bunkers called Vaults without much knowledge about the world above. You are tasked with saving your home after the water production breaks down.

Before you jump ship and begin the quest to SAVE THE WORLD by killing some rats, you need to define your character. I found there was no right or wrong way to do this. Just that each choice will affect your adventure. Choosing a low Strength attribute won't allow you to lug around all the junk that you find. Agility effects action points in combat and how many gun shots you can attempt. Luck, usually a garbage stat effects your critical chances and also your random encounters. You also have skills and traits to choose and develop.

You can't have a character that does everything well so you need to make choices on your play style. Go mighty sledgehammer or become a thief and pickpocket to riches. Specialise as a sniper or as a psycho killer, destroying everything that gives you a dirty look. Mwuahhaha!

Saving your vault from water starvation is a small part of the overall story. It really gets interesting later on as you explore the desert and come across large towns and even a giant cathedral. Necropolis is full of zombie like ghouls and a super mutant group are on the rampage killing all before them. Then we have Deathclaws - legendary creatures that I found extremely vexing and impossible to take down. Eventually I figured out how shoot them in the leg or eyeballs.

So, read the manual and figure out how to interact with the world. There is a learning curve and at the beginning you will feel lost. Damn - where are those pointers saying go there and do that. The end story was quite interesting and I really wish I could do a third play through - but on to Fallout 2.

Oh - and don't ignore the timer to complete the initial water quest. I did on my first play through and the game promptly stopped when it said it would.

Oh, I came across a TARDIS in the wastelands and then an alien ship that had crashed that contained a picture of Elvis. I also found an alien blaster that was awesome.

Fantastic gem of a game. 8/10 as a modern game.

reviewText:
[Note: The game time logged on Steam does not reflect the time I spent playing Fallout to date. I bought it back in 1997 on CD-ROM and have owned a couple of other bundles which included it since, and have completed Fallout at least a dozen of times since first release.]

This was the very first of the Fallout games, and it is still in my all-time-favorite games list today. With added community enhancements, hi-res patches and unofficial updates, this game is still fun, unique to play, and more complex than it was on its release date; and the best part is, even a low-powered netbook can run this just fine. The post-apocalyptic world is diverse, the humor is brilliant to say the least, and this game is just worth being played just for the random encounters alone.

The character creation is fun, you get a wide array of cool weapons (such a modified shotgun based pistol!), and even after a number of playthroughs, there are still new items to discover. If you love RPGs, if you love a post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting, and if you have an affinity for the Fallout universe (even if you started with Fallout 3), then you should certainly give this a try, even if it might look a little dated. The graphics, as they are, in fact help the atmosphere. I probably completed this game over a dozen times.

Given the fact that Fallout is from 1997, a time in which video games were not quite established yet as a socially accepted entertainment form, the voice acting provided by actors like Ron Perlman, Michael Dorn and Dwight Schultz is also superb! If you don't like this game, you were born a generation too late and I feel sorry for you!

reviewText:
My Fallout experiences and what I thought of Fallout: A Post Nuclear Role Playing Game

My introduction to the Fallout franchise was through a friend of my elder brothers. Before going out, he peered his head into my room and left an Xbox 360 copy of Fallout 3 on my table for me to borrow. I was addicted. The start of the summer of 09' was spent wondering the DC ruins and soaking up everything that that insane game had to offer.

A year later in 2010, New Vegas had came out. I ravenously guzzled it down within a month and was still hungry for more. For a massive history-buff like me, and all though it's set in the 2100's, the Fallout series offered a unique experience and had me totally engrossed in it's seemingly endless codex-like information and lore.

So, some time later it is payday December 2013. By now I am on Steam (albeit still a noob) and I am searching the store. I get home from a freezing night of Christmas shopping with the girlfriend, and I notice the 'Fallout Bundle' going for around £3. Was this real?

As soon as Fallout 1 had Installed I jumped on in.

It took a while to get used to the old turn taking system, but you have to be open minded. Playing game series backwards in age is going to be off putting so you have to try and enjoy it for what it is. Saying this though, I got bored (Guilty as charged) and didn't play it for about half a year. As much as it pains me to say this, I just lost my will to play it entirely from sheer boredom.

Into the not-so-distant future and the Fallout crave had started to come back. I reinstalled F:aPNRPG and jumped on into a new game. This time round, I curbed my ego and instead of playing Fallout 1 like I played Fallout 3 and NV, I decided to take a completely different approach.

I forced myself to remember, this game was made when I was fifteen months old. Times were different back then. So I dumped myself in the desk chair, grabbed a tall drink of cola and walked out into the Vault 13 Caves.

I didn't look back, and what a game it was. A solid 10/10. A beautifully minimalist/simple and believable plot too. Try it for yourself.

If you are approaching this game from the future like I did, then be open minded. Only play it when you crave to. Otherwise you'll get bored and this gem will be missed out on.

Next up, Fallout 2.

reviewText: My first Fallout games were Fallout 3, and New Vegas. While I was initially attracted to the fact that those games were 3D, and to an extent First Person Shooters, it was the story and character development that kept me playing Fallout for hours on end. Having just played through the original Fallout, I can say that the original is just as good, if not better considering that the game is now 16 years old.\n\nI laughed when the PC demanded donuts from thugs, I cried when my poor decisions lead to Dogmeats death, I saved Southern California from a dangerous cult. 10/10

reviewText: Great game for fallout lore, which is why I love it, but not for much else. if you buy it on sale it is well worth the money. The story is exelent and the gameplay is fun but a bit restrictive due to it's age. If you love the fallout universe and want the full experience this game is for you. There are a few major issues though, if a companion dies and you do not exit the cell reloading the save with the companion dead will crash the game. Once a compainion dies you have no save slot, but it really isn't much of an issue, just save before battles and dismiss compainons if they keep dying and you need the ability to reload a mid battle save.

reviewText:
[Note: The game time logged on Steam does not reflect the time I spent playing Fallout to date. I bought it back in 1997 on CD-ROM and have owned a couple of other bundles which included it since, and have completed Fallout at least a dozen of times since first release.]

This was the very first of the Fallout games, and it is still in my all-time-favorite games list today. With added community enhancements, hi-res patches and unofficial updates, this game is still fun, unique to play, and more complex than it was on its release date; and the best part is, even a low-powered netbook can run this just fine. The post-apocalyptic world is diverse, the humor is brilliant to say the least, and this game is just worth being played just for the random encounters alone.

The character creation is fun, you get a wide array of cool weapons (such a modified shotgun based pistol!), and even after a number of playthroughs, there are still new items to discover. If you love RPGs, if you love a post-apocalyptic sci-fi setting, and if you have an affinity for the Fallout universe (even if you started with Fallout 3), then you should certainly give this a try, even if it might look a little dated. The graphics, as they are, in fact help the atmosphere. I probably completed this game over a dozen times.

Given the fact that Fallout is from 1997, a time in which video games were not quite established yet as a socially accepted entertainment form, the voice acting provided by actors like Ron Perlman, Michael Dorn and Dwight Schultz is also superb! If you don't like this game, you were born a generation too late and I feel sorry for you!

reviewText: Fallout is quite an experience. Like most games, Fallout has its quarks and times when you get a little frustrated at a small detail or lack there of. However, for myself, when I began to play Fallout I was enthrolled with the world in which I was to explore. Being a vet of Fallout 3 and New Vegas I wasn't sure how I would feel about a tactical turn based combat system. I was pleasantly surprised to find out how much it felt like I was playing a tabletop RPG. All in all, Fallout is a game I will always remember fondly with its exciting quest plots and interesting characters and situations. But it's downsides were slightly taxing, I would say it is worth $10 but if you get it on sale it is absolutly worth the time and investment.

reviewText: My first Fallout game was Fallout 3. I was amased by the game. The wasteland and its characters, the dark humour, the intense atmosphere, the kind of game you could just dive into. Being completely new to the fallout universe, I didn't knew anything about the original Fallout or Fallout 2. Since I liked Fallout 3 so much, I decided to try the original one.\n\nThe game is GREAT. The graphics, a bit shabby for today's standards, don't diminishes it in any circunstance. In fact, they are very nice, considering it's a very old game. The atmosphere was there from the start. From the introduction, to the gameplay, dungeons, characters, quests, the same eerie yet enthralling wasteland feel. The turn-based gameplay it's very interesting, considering it forces you to have a real rpg experience, differently from Fallout 3, that could be played as a action" rpg. The music and sound effects are deep and enhances the experience a lot. The valt dweller's mission makes you really worry while travelling. Gathering information is a must
date: and every new bit of information leads you to new places and new experiences. A great game indeed. If you play it and like it
recommended: I highly recommend playing Fallout 2 also.\n\n"

reviewText:
My first Fallout game was Fallout 2.  This plays just like that.  Great tactical combat, and roleplay experiences.  I like the choices you can make, obviously 2 was more polished and had more humor, although I am only 2 hours in so maybe their will be more humor as I progress.

Anyway, if you like tactical turn based RPGs and post apoclypatic settings then you should really play this game.  Also steam has fixed issues with it not running on modern computers correctly.  I am playing only via steam and everything works great, and it seems to support modern resolutions.

I would like to add this game does not hold your hand.  If gives you a mission and sends you out the door with a small lead.   It's up to you to figure out what to do from then on out, it's not mission based but fairly open world.

reviewText:
One of those Golden Classics, the Combat can be a bit slow, you might be a bit used to Autosave and forget to save now and then, but definatly worth it.

Agility and Intelligence is quite important in the two first fallout game as Action Point and Skill Points are your bread and butter. There are also possible to pick up books to acquire skills to a relative high level, and in this game you can even buy them from a store in the Hub. I suggest Saving often, especially before you start quests and the like because the game run on its own time table once you take a quest, and the bad guys might kill the good guy because you used to long. Which is one of the things I used to love about this game.

Getting a Power Armor really makes things easier as it boost your strength with 2 so you never really need more than 8 in strength as 10 is maximum, Ranged Fighting is definatly the way to go so I really suggest stacking agility, perception and intelligence above the other stats (or cheat all the stats to 10 in everything :D) Anyhow the story is amazing, the music gives me goose bumps, and blasting muties to high heaven with a rocket launcher or saw em in half with my lazer gatling gun or Turbo-charged Plasma Rifle..... Worth every god damn penny.

I think that Bethesda never did Fallout 1 or 2 any justice, it was like Fallout Tactics was placed in 3D, without the option for multiple party members.  I know I am a Bioware Fanboy, but I think they would have done a 1000 times better job with the game series than Bethesda ever could hope to come up with. But this isnt about those awful games that came after these gems... Fallout 1 and 2 are worth it.

reviewText:
To me, Fallout is THE definitive RPG, similar to Doom being THE definitive shooter. Although the world offers a lot of depth, it affects the player directly enough to inspire purpose. For example, it has more story compared to Icewind dale, but is not as long-winded as Baldur's Gate. Nevertheless, the writing is superb and combined with an amazing soundtrack it creates a memorable retro-futuristic experience. The game is also more open – there is a map, but it's up to you to discover if, when and where you will travel. Even though combat is turn-based, it is surprisingly packed with action. Just make double sure to turn combat speed all the way to maximum in options. Even today, one has to appreciate the animations when you blow a hole through an enemy's torso or cut him in half with a laser rifle.

I think that since its release, I completed this game at least 50 times. So why do I still consider it worth playing after so many years, since I pretty much know its world like my own backyard? Despite all of this, there is still plenty of variety in the game. You see, the player has a great deal of control over how linear, open, short or long the playthrough is, even though you do not realize it at the beginning. So first, there are so many different approaches and play styles simply related to what kind of character you design and act as (commando, sniper, spy, librarian, doctor, pacifist, Hodor, etc.). Then there is the absolutely amazing diversity of how you deal with problems. When you complete it more than one time you will sometimes think: “Wow, I did not of this before!” Let me just point out that it is possible to complete Fallout 1 by leaving behind hundreds of corpses or by never killing anyone (I am not kidding). It all depends on how you observe, interpret and act upon the game world.

And finally, there is our mistress random chance. Her effects are subtle and never in the game you get the feeling that regardless of your skill it all comes down to a coin toss (like in FTL, for example). But they are present enough for the game to be able to surprise you regardless of how well you know it. For example, in my many playthroughs only once I had such amazing luck that after leaving Vault 15 I was ambushed by a well armed party and after disposing of them I received a much better armor than is expected at that point in the game. Almost immediately after that I encountered a merchant party and decided on a whim to be an evil materialist. I put my above average gear to use and slaughtered them all. As I prepared my backpack full of goods to be sold later and thinking things can't get any better at this point, I received the Alien Blaster special encounter (never happened to me so early in the game). So before I even got to the Raiders or Junktown, I was already outfitted well enough to be a real threat to basically anyone in the game with the correct use of tactics. And on the other end – only once I had such bad luck that before reaching Vault 15, I was ambushed so severely that there was no way to ever win and I had to try very hard several times to even escape alive.
